description:
Found out these kind of place exist after going to the one in nyc and I love the environment! Grab a sausage and a litter of beer and have fun and be with friends or meet new ones!

Staff are really nice and it's at such a nice spot in Hayes valley near a bunch of amazing! 

We got litter and half a litter of their dark and light beer! I like the dark ones better. Sausages were pretty good but their sliders and guest knot was ! Highly recommend trying the guest knot! So delicious! definitely my favorite item that we ordered! This place got me all excited and ready for Oktoberfest!
author: Christopher G.

description:
Long gone are the dive bars and beergardens of yore. In their stead lie establishments such as Biergarten Hayes Valley! Pretty good and overpriced...

Let me explain. I enjoy this place. The service was friendly and prompt. I got the burger with arugula Swiss and deli mustard, for $8, and a liter of German style beer for $20. That's right, each ounce of this beer cost me approximately $0.59. *sips slowly* Aaahhhh...

The burger was a slider. There's no way around it. My friend got a bratwurst which he described as a Costco hot dog in a sourdough bun that was toasted on the outside only, which was $11. I anticipate his review will yield one star if he doesn't pass out from hunger before posting it. I personally am having a friend pick up food for me so that I survive a bar crawl tonight.

Overall, delicious experience for me, but the prices reflect a level of inflation we shouldn't hit for another 27 years. 

Prost!
author: Richard J.

description:
Ever since going to Munich a few years ago, I've also wanted to experience an outdoor beer garden in the states. This place doesn't really replicate that since they're serving beer out of a shipping container, but gives it a SF spin to it. 

Prices here are fairly reasonable, 0.5L for $9, 1L for $18. They sell radlers here so if you're not a huge fan of beer, this is a great alternative since it's half beer and half citrus juice. 

When I went on a Saturday evening it was extremely lively and packed full of people. Loved the atmosphere! Definitely check it out if you like your beer with Stein glasses.
author: Edward W.

description:
Very crowded and not many places to sit. Expect to stand for a while until a little portion of the table opens up. There were only two of us but we had to wait about 15 min until 2 spots opened.

The garden is pretty nice and the beer is decently priced.
author: Ash S.

description:
Outdoor seating and beer? How can you go wrong! I suppose if you really hate German beer and sausages and this is not the place for you, but even then it might be because you can still sit outside with your friends and eat pretzels and drink cider so really you have nothing to lose.

All of their beer is German beer which is important to know, but if you like trying German beers this is a great place to try a few different varieties. You can also get full liters (those big steines you think of when you think german beer) which is always fun. 

They also have a bunch of different food including sausages and pretzels and sandwiches and pickles and other appetizers. I got the curry wurst last time which tasted like curry wurst! The pretzels were also quite good we also got potato dumplings which were quite tasty.

The best part about this place though definitely is that it's all outdoor seating. They have big long picnic tables by lots of people can sit outside in the sun. They also have some of them covered with a tent though so if you have a baby that needs protection from the sun like I do you're still set. I totally disagree that this place is bad for kids. Maybe not good for kids I suppose but fine for babies - I was not the only one there with an infant. It's easy to bring a stroller in too. Only warning here is that it is pretty loud. 

Be warned! This place gets busy! So get there early. It's order at the counter and they give you your beer right there and then bring you your food but the line get so long it goes out of the garden and down the sidewalk.
author: Sarah C.

description: I do enjoy their potato salad, but I decided to try the "meat knot" today. The knot is just a pretzel with something inside. This one had like a slice of prosciutto or something. It was terribly overpriced at $7 and not worth it. It should be like $4.50-$5.00 and no more than that. It is a snack and not a meal. You can get a burrito in SF for $7, but a "knot" is not of that filling proportion, so I can't recommend a "knot." The potato salad is almost divine. Those benches for seating are a pain in the a** though.
author: Denise C.

description: Fun place to just chill, eat and drink. Line to order is a bit long and slow but service is fast. I haven't tried their food, except for the preztel, which is good with their mustard or horseradish sauces. Definitely come here for great tasting German beers in a liter!
author: Christine A.

description:
Great place to sit around and drink, at least until the sun sets. Once that happens, the cold artic wind begins to blow in from the north and the direwolves begin to howl...

...but before that, you can drink liters upon liters of beer and sit at semi-communal tables. It's usually pretty full but you can usually find a place to sit after a few minutes of standing around. They have food too, but besides the pretzel, everything is kinda just OK.
author: Tea W.

description:
There was a time when I lived in Hayes Valley.  My landlord, who lived on Upper Polk, had bought a condo on Page Street and when I informed her that I'd be moving out she said "I was hoping that neighborhood would be better by now.  That was supposed to be my retirement home".  

That was in the late 1980's, when a freeway ran right through the neighborhood and hookers solicited business beneath that freeway, at least on Page Street.  That landlord may be long gone but her dream of an improved Hayes Valley has arrived.  What a change 30 years makes.
 
Though there's a million booze and food choices lining Hayes Street, Biergarten sits off Patricia's Green, hidden amongst the shipping containers offering coffee, juice, and ice cream.  Its popularity makes clear that it's no secret, but unless you're looking for it it'd be easy to miss.    

There's nothing here to go crazy over but the appeal of casual al fresco dining and drinking (especially in the heat of late) is attractive.  Having hit Berlin at the beginning of winter, when their biergartens had mostly moved indoors, Biergarten stood in as a worthy surrogate.  

I sampled only beer, a warm pretzel, and potato salad ($6) and feel confident in reporting that Biergarten will fill your gut without raiding your savings.  It inspired my partner, with his 1/2 pint beer, to look around at the full pints and offer "I'd like to come back here again" (no doubt for more beer).  

With the picnic tables pretty full my 2-person party did little to skew the average patron age at Biergarten which otherwise skews young.  Still, nobody looked askance at those of us who remember this area from a time that pre-dates their birth certificate.  Despite the crowd, Biergarten proved to be good for all ages and, though I saw a dog there I notice that their web site says "no pets".  That right there might be the worst thing about the place. 

Bier, filling German fare, and sunshine; what's not to like?
author: Tracey A.

description:
Came here for the currywurst and the pickles.  Both of which were very well done.  I have been back for more.  The atmosphere is outdoor, and really nice.  You likely will share a table with someone else, and everyone is really friendly.  They have a great beer selection.  

The sliders were OK.  Pork belly, so you can't go wrong, right?  Well, kinda.  They were unremarkable.  So stick with the sausages, and cut them with the pickles, then wash it all down with a good beer.
author: Benjamin H.

description:
Consistently good food and revolving menu of German beers. Great for sitting in the sun and having an afternoon with friends. They even have blankets for when the fog rolls in and pop-up tents if it gets drizzly. What's not to like?

I honestly can't think of a food item where you can go wrong, but my favorite is the egg sandwich and pretzel knots (when available).
author: david m.

description:
Great outdoor space in an amazing location in Hayes Valley. I came here on a Saturday afternoon with some friends. It was pretty crowded but we were able to snag a seat at an open table right away. It is all outdoor seating and there are big picnic table so you will likely share with other people depending on bow big your group is. 

You go up the counter to order. Good beer list and they serve them in big authentic steins. We ordered the pretzel and it wasn't great. It was pretty small and was cold and hard. 

There is no indoors seating so be sure to bring a jacket because it can get chilly. They also have blankets you can use if you get cold. 

Overall it's a great spot to come with a group of friends on a sunny day. I will definitely be back.
author: Taylor F.

description:
First off, Hayes Valley is known for being a little on the pricier end of San Francisco neighborhoods. Lots of good restaurants and bars, classy dining spots and overall upscale-suburban/middle-class consumer friendly.

First things first, it's a great spot. Casual outdoor patio eatery, classic German beer garden. I came during a sunny weeknight after people got out of work and there were a lot of people there -- somehow beat the line and was able to still snag a spot cozied up to other people. Their menu features German dogs, pickled foods, pretzels, cheeses, meats and veggies... Seems heavy?

I went for their Mushroom Portobello Sliders and I think they were about the GREATEST THINGS I HAVE EVER HAD. Warm soft golden crisp brioche bun, fresh and generous amount of arugula for a good bite,  goat cheese, hefty tomato and one damn tasty thick portobello mushroom in between. I've had my fair share of mushroom sliders/burgers in the past but nothing beat how tasty these things were. Plus, their pints/glasses of beers were affordable AND pretty tall.

For a beer garden, Biergarten does it right. Damn tasty food, great neighborhood and local vibe, great patio space and quick friendly service. They bring you your food with your number when it's ready while you can casually sip on your German beer. This is a great spot and I'd easily come back. No questions asked.
author: Rachel Ann C.

description: This place is great for a nice and sunny day. The set up with the long bench tables is nice and the food is amazing. I highly suggest checking out this place!
author: Y S.

description:
This is always one of the first places my friends and I think of going when we want to enjoy a rare sunny and warm San Francisco day (after spending time at Dolores or Fort Mason, of course). 

Outdoor seating, great German beer, and in the wonderful Hayes Valley neighborhood where you can hop around afterwards. Many people come with their dogs and babies. 

Not into beer? They have cider and wine options too. 

The food is OK. Not amazing but definitely not bad. I do enjoy their deviled eggs and pretzels, just not the best I've ever had. You order at the counter and then find seating on long picnic tables. This place does get busy, so be prepared for a wait. You're near many great restaurants so you can always eat elsewhere and just enjoy a beverage and being outside here.

If it does get cold, or you don't feel like waiting for a warm day, they have blankets you can cuddle up in.
author: Sonal K.

description: Mealiest Bratwurst ever! Mealy mealy mealy!AchtungStay away from Bratwurst  Schmeckt wie Sägemehl! Tastes like sawdust. Other than that, fun place good beer, pretzels, Pickels -meet people at the tablles
author: Michael H.

description:
Great outdoor vibe
Giant mugs are available 
A wide range of draft beers
Food is also served
Seating can fill up fast especially on our rare nice warm days

Overall Thoughts

Beer + Outdoor vibes = fun times
author: Eddie W.

description:
I like beer. No, I love beer. No, as a matter of fact, I practically have a drinking problem when it comes to beer. So when my friends started going to Biergarten (I pronounce it as Beer Garden because I'm not pretentious) regularly, life became absolutely wunderbar (ok, maybe a little pretentious).

Biergarten was made for a degenerate like myself. It is a place of unadulterated drinking. Within its chic outdoor confines, no one judges you for indulging in a few extra drinks, because hell, their judgement is probably impaired! 

There are a selection of about 5 beers. I forget what they all are exactly because when it comes to beer, I don't discriminate. The more important choice you have to make is choosing the size of the beer. DON'T GET THE SMALL ONE. If you want to be one of those "I'm just here for the company" people, then yeah go for the small one. No one will ever respect you, though. Everyone should get the large. It comes in a big ol' stein with one liter of goodness poured inside. As a punny friend of mine once said, it's outsteinding. 

Many a times I had held that sturdy stein by the handle with anticipation frothing in my mind. Holding heavy in my hands, the golden lager seduces my senses until I give in passionately to my urge. The soft white foam brushes briefly beneath my nose, like the ripples from a calm summer wave. Then a gush of cold, refreshing beer bursts through. Oh! So cold, so sweet, so satisfying! *Gulp* *Gulp* *Gulp* AHHHHHHH. So satisfying indeed. 

But alas, I can no longer indulge in this fine pleasure from Biergarten. One fateful Friday night, when I was throwing down the last of my liter stein, I saw something that I simply cannot erase from my memory. Three little mice skittered nonchalantly around that one shipping container at the edge. I was a little intoxicated at that point, so it may have been three big rats (or Three Blind Mice) for all I know. 

I can't do it, I just can't. 

I still love beer. But I fear rats. I guess my fear of rats is greater than that of my love for beer. So then I guess maybe I am not a degenerate? Or maybe just a cowardly one.
author: Ringo M.

description:
We came to this place as part of a pub crawl that a coworker put together. They are beer and wine only and are fully outdoor.  We got here around 10 pm and it was freezing, we probably would not have stayed here if we were not a part of the group as we were too cold.

We had a beer and the pretzel and their cheese app. I am not sure if I was misreading the menu or just assumed what I wanted but I thought the cheese would be a hot dip for my warm pretzel.  I was wrong, it was cold and odd. It had a heavy blue cheese-ish flavor and I was not a fan. The pretzel was good, just like most bar pretzels. It came with mustard and fresh horseradish. I would recommend the pretzel but I would not get the cheese again.

Many people with us ordered the pork sliders and seemed to enjoy them but this was our 3rd bar stop so I am not sure if they were delicious or just necessary. 

I would come back earlier in the day when the sun is shining when I want to sit on a patio,  but I do not think this is a place that I would seek out or go out of my way for.
author: Danielle B.

description:
This is a fantastic outdoor open area place that will surely transport you to Germany!!

The atmosphere is ELECTRIC but a good kind of electric as everyone is happy and drunk off beer and not sloppy nor obscene.

The food here is also BOMB!! Do yourself a favor and order one of their sausages (it usually comes with soft and supple fried potatoes -- THE BEST!!). Seriously the meat is just cooked to perfection. So juicy and pairs so nicely with the potato and the BEER!

It's first come first serve seating and can get backed during seasonal hours but I'd wait just to eat and live it up here because it's casual, fun, and non-pretentious just the way I like it!

Psssssstttt..... don't order a dinky little pint go big or go home!
author: Connie M.

description:
Really cool spot when the weather's nice in the city.  They had 4 beers on tap (3 German and 1 by Fort Point) and come in two different sizes.  Half a liter goes for around $8 and a full liter can be $18-20 depending on your choice.  

There's a good amount of seating but on a nice day in SF, the seats can fill up fast.  There's also usually a line to buy your beer.  I wouldn't mind standing when the seats are all full, but with a liter glass full of beer, your arm gets tired after 10 minutes.  Great place to go with a group of friends or just a couple.  

The only bad thing I have to say is that they open at 3pm on Saturdays.  I wish they were open earlier to enjoy the afternoon sun.
author: Justin Y.

description:
Only had their Gnome burger so far, but it was the very best type of snack.
+1/4 a pound of beef that was flavorful and seared so well, it tasted almost like there was bacon in it.
+Refreshing arugula, which added just a nice bite to counter balance the meatiness. Even my partner who normally doesn't like arugula thought it added a nice flavor
+Delicious mustard. Even though I ordinarily don't like mustard, it had a pretty light flavor and the type was actually tasty. I might have to revisit different types of mustard.
+Everything was well balanced, from the bread, to meat, to condiments. Only negative was that I didn't order 2!

Will definitely be back for beer and other snacks. Yum!
author: Anna D.

description:
I've lived in Germany for a month before and this place really brought me back to some good times.  I'm not a huge drinker (but come on just get the big liter for the snaps) so I'll focus my review on the food, which I felt was pretty legit.  

I loved the bratwurst, especially with the potatoes.  The pork belly sliders are a must.  Throw in a pretzel into the mix!  The Wednesday burger looked so amazing that I felt compelled to get it, but surprisingly not my fav.  Just get more sliders to share!

The outdoor seating is really cute.  When it started to get chilly, a really nice lady brought out these really heavy blankets for us.
author: Shannon L.

description:
Ooohhh we had us a good time here on Saturday for day dranks. Too bad it was colder than hell and we weren't dressed appropriately, otherwise we would've stayed much longer. Biergarten is a legit beer garden, meaning, no indoor places for you to hide. The beers are served from this sort of food-trucky spot but they're huge, delicious, crisp, and pretty affordable. Food is also ordered from the same space and comes out only a few minutes later.

LOVED their organic hefeweizen, as well as their curry potatoes and pork sliders. We will definitely be back again, this time more clothed. Love that dogs and children are allowed to join in the fun. Good times had by all.
author: Joanna R.

description:
Hi from your German that moved to the U.S. a few years ago.

+ The beer selection is good (I saw a few posts that say it doesn't have enough but even Biergarten in Germany have like 5 - 6 different types -- I don't understand why you'd like 30 different beer types). Order Andechs if you don't know what you like.
+ The tables and benches are typically German and it's outdoors. That's the only reason I come back.
+ They offer Glühwein in the winter.

- Unfortunately, the food is not German at all. Some other people said it's authentic but trust me: it's not. We would never eat Bratwurst in the way they serve it, neither Currywurst and we don't eat our Pretzels (Brezen) warm. I wouldn't even like it if it was an American restaurant.
- There is no decoration at all. For an authentic Biergarten I'd expect a bit more than just a parking lot with a fence.
- It's expensive and the food is not worth the money. 
- The local crowd is usually the typical tech crowd that you see everywhere which is why it doesn't feel like a real Biergarten at all (at least to me because I grew up with them).

Overall, I'm still going there because they sell my favorite beer and I like to drink beer outside but I wouldn't come there for the food or the atmosphere.
author: Maria H.

description: Nice way to kick off Oktoberfest. Gets really crowded really fast. A nice not huge selection of beers. Went with the wheat beer and the bratwurst. The beer was very good and the bratwurst was surprisingly very delicious. The mustard and garlic really made it. Would def come back!
author: Linda H.

description:
We scored VIP parking in this area so we decided to take advantage of it and walk around.  After stepping into two coffee shops and not purchasing anything, we stumbled upon Biergarten; beer it is.  Big, open space with lots of seating.  They even provide blankets which is a huge plus especially on those cold SF days.

Currywurst - I love me some sausage, especially the tip.  I normally don't like to eat sausage/hot dogs with a bun so I was glad to see toasted bread on the side.  The curry wasn't overwhelming.  They also slice the sausage into pieces for you.  

Service is efficient and friendly.
author: Linda N.

description: Amazing location, really good choice of beers, really cool atmosphere and really good sausages, if you know what I mean  (but actually though really good sausages)
author: Hagop B.

description:
Take me to a beer garden and I'll love you forever! (Maybe, possibly, or you know prob not - but we'll be on a good level! Beer friends!).

I came here on a mission for wieners and a liter of beer & folks, I think we all can agree that a visit to Biergarten for those two items will breed success. While they do not have a huge selection of draft beers to choose from there is a good variety to choose from (i.e. if you're an IPA fan, lager, etc. - pretty likely there's something out there to meet any beer connoisseurs tastebuds!). 

Honestly, there's nothing better to me than hanging out with my friends and enjoying their company with beer and noms in hand! You first order your beers and food then you're able to get a number so they can bring your food to you! It's important to note that things can get pretty busy here, so finding seating can be a challenge but is doable with a bit of patience and if you or your pals are willing to act like vultures for seats! There's no shame here because literally I spotted three other parties doing the exact same thing! 

Also, with the weather dwindling down and for nights that are pretty chilly I think it's pretty nifty  that get this - Biergarten provides blankets for when it gets a little chilly! Woooooo, do it for the warmth (and the beers)! 

Cheers fellow Yelpers and maybe I'll catch you at the Biergarten one day! :)
author: Janelle V.

description: Get the pretzel. I would skip the deviled eggs, pork sliders, and curry worst next time and opt for trying some new things
author: Laura D.

description:
Great vibes and beer selection for bar crawl beginnings; But just ok service and food

Alcohol: Pure cider rose with black currant ($7). This was very yummy as a non-beer and alcohol appreciator. My friends also got other draft beers/dark stouts and they seemed to enjoy it.

Food: I was so excited to try the pretzel bun since I never had it, so I ordered the frankfurter. Only for the cashier (who looked as enthused to be working on a Friday night as I would be) to tell me they had ran out of the buns. I said that was fine. Except I noticed she still charged the full $8 for a frankfurter missing the bun...Not the type to contest 45 mins before closing so I decided to just be happy to get food. But even the frankfurter (imagine a mushier Costco hot dog) and sauerkraut (not very pickly/crisp) were just meh. 

Service: The cashier/bartender just didn't look happy to be there or happy that anyone was there, and that just puts me off. Like people are here on a Friday night excited to try the food and the drinks. The server however was very friendly and quick to bring out the food.

Vibes: Great vibes and outdoor lighting. The people who come are the non-rowdy, let's just enjoy each other's company type which was great. No outdoor heating, so it get pretty chilly! They also close early for a bar (9pm), so definitely a starting place for a bar crawl in Hayes Valley or an ice cream outing at the Smitten next door.
author: Cindy L.

description: I absolutely love this place but there's always a huge line when it's nice out. I'd recommend ordering everything you plan to eat/drink the first time you stand in line because the line is consistently 15-20 minutes. Also if you order 1 pickle you get like 10
author: Wendy K.

description:
A relatively small (or often packed) beer garden, this place offers a small selection of German beers and a decent selection of food, whether sausages, sliders, sandwiches, salads, or burgers. 

It's less about the food and drink itself than about hanging out, seeing, and being seen with large groups of your bros or your yupster friends. Service is fast and efficient though, and, in a nice touch, if it gets cold out they have blankets to lend. 

There's not much else in the way of ambience besides having good company. Quite a vanilla scene. For beer gardens with real character and zero pretense, head on over to Oakland and try out Telegraph, Lost & Found, or Hella Vegan Eats.
author: Vincent L.

description: Two beers and two hot dogs for 80 dollars. The guy at the counter acted like he was doing is a favor by pouring a beer. They get an extra star for the outside area and the fact they provide blankets when it gets chilly, but I don't think I can justify ever going back.
author: Hannah G.

description: Absolutely love this place for a sunday afternoon or friday night beer. The ambiance is great but I only wish they had a wider range and selection of beers. Will definitely be back with a big group of people to pretend we are in Munich at Oktoberfest!
author: Rachel N.

description: This is such a fun and different bar to try! Definitely get a stein and enjoy the atmosphere! Everything is outside but they have plenty of blankets and some covering so you never get cold! This place is always buzzing on a Saturday afternoon in the sunshine.
author: Lauren A.

description:
A great place to grab a beer or two (OR be a champ and get a stein). Good selection of German beers available to choose from. Plenty of seating. The only downside is that it's outdoors so if you get cold easily you'll want to bring a thick warm jacket to fight off the chilly evening SF wind. They have thick blankets available for use (limited supply). 

Don't get excited if you see brezel or pretzel on the menu. We ordered one thinking it was a pretzel. It's not the type of pretzel you would normally get from a ballpark or mall, but a small circular patty of sorts. Wouldn't recommend ordering it based off of the taste/flavors. I would return on a nice sunny day just for the beer.
author: Saachi G.

description:
This is an awesome little spot with a crazy line! We lined up about 20 minutes before it opened, so we were able to grab a table quickly and get our beers and brats. The brats were delicious here, and the German beers were thirst-quenching! I chose the dark beer because it was the strongest :)

The line was super long the whole hour we were sitting, eating, drinking and laughing. We didn't want to go back in line so we left after our first round. Plus, we were SO FULL and couldn't drink another sip of beer or even look at the food anymore.

If you can, get here before they open so you don't need to wait 30+ minutes!
author: Michael K.

description:
Came here after work to hang out with a friend after work! Biergarten is such a cute spot to get a beer and snacks with a small or large group on a laidback sunny day.  I love how they have light hanging over a bunch of picnic tables that are arranged in a circle.  

The beer comes by the liter which is perfect, just like in Munchen ;P They even have steins from Hofbrauhaus and other places in Germany! The food is also delicious, but they are very small in portion and size.  I got the pretzel knot with bananas and it was amazing, but not filling and very small.  I would say this is an appetizer for a bigger meal later.  

Very cute place to stop by.  Definitely recommend. 

PS if it gets cold, they even provide large wool blankets.

Atmosphere: 4/5
Food and Drink: 4/5
Service: 4/5
Overall Experience: 4/5
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
Nice place to hang out with friends on a Sunday afternoon over a pint of Radley(?), which I learned is beer mixed with a sparkly lemon liquid thing. Haha don't know what exactly it was but it was light, sweet and refreshing! Con is the price at $9 a pint.

I really appreciated the complimentary thick blankets they have for customers to use since it's quite chilly in SF to be hanging out outdoors right by Fell st. 

Conveniently located in Hayes Valley next to many food options (though they do have some snacks here as well) and right next to Smitten if you're craving ice cream after!

Would come back!
author: Carissa G.

description:
Came here for a late afternoon drink yesterday and will definitely be back to hang out longer and try more things.

This is basically a glorified parking lot filled with picnic tables and 2 cargo containers, 1 for beer and ordering food and 1 for making food.  I didn't eat here, but the food smelled absolutely fantastic so I will need to go back and order more food.

They have a great selection of German beers and you can order a half litre or full litre.  Very similar to an outside biergarten at Oktoberfest or in Munich in general, where you smoosh yourselves into those picnic tables with random strangers and drink beer.

It got a bit cold and windy and even with venue-provided blankets it was too cold for me to stay outside much longer.  Would be a great place to go on a warm day!
author: Jade R.

description:
What a great place to hang out! I love Biergarten. I am a lover of all beers and delicious bar food and Biergarten delivers on both accounts. 

+ ATMOSPHERE: Outdoors, very hip, tons of picnic table style seating, twinkly string lights, and food truck-ish vibes. I've been here twice so far; once after work and once right when they opened on a Sunday. After work, it was CRAZY PACKED. Like brimming with techies and hipsters. EVERYWHERE. It's hard to find a seat. The other time, we got there right when it opened at 1 PM ish so it wasn't packed but it filled up within the hour. So definitely try to plan accordingly because it'll be hard to find seating unless you're lucky. Biergarten is very casual and a great spot to hang out with friends. It's sort of like someone's backyard hang out spot. It's chill. It's cool. I dig it.

+ BEER/FOOD: The beer is expensive (typical of SF of course). Choices are somewhat limited. But very good beers. There are half liter and full liter options. I think most of the liters were ~$20 and half liters ranged from ~$8-10 each. Tons of food on the menu though! So many German food options! I ordered the pretzel because I wasn't incredibly hungry. It came with some spicy mustard and horse radish. DELISH. SO SOFT. I love soft pretzels. I wanna try the other food on the menu! My friend ordered the Guest Knot and he thoroughly enjoyed it as well. 

+ THE FINAL VERDICT: Biergarten is a great German inspired beer garden. I'm a fan of course, but mostly for the atmosphere. I love the outdoor seating and how everything's set up. It's a perfect place to chill and hang out with friends. Very casual and laid back. The food and beer is solid. There are more choices for food than there are for beers, which is a little upsetting because I love my beer -- but I can deal because I mainly come here to hang out.
author: Amy T.

description: Have been here several times. Love the snacky food. Gets very crowded in the early evening on nice weather days. There's a bathroom available even though the seating is outdoors.
author: Kayla M.

description:
Great beer, great German food! Seating is outdoor on picnic tables...so come dressed appropriately if you plan on eating here because it gets cold and windy in sf! 

I ordered the wursthurt...the sausage was amazing. The curry potatoes were good too. The beer mug is huge though..I got the half liter one and was struggling to finis that. They do close very early on sunday...7pm. Right across from them is smitten ice cream so you can make your way over after for some desserts. 

Seating is sharing picnic tables with other people which is a very German thing to do, I think.  Great ambience, great atmosphere!!
author: Caitlin P.

description: Oh, Biergarten. You hold a wonderful place in my heart. Wonderful on sunny days, and worth the chill on cold evening when the staff provide wool blankets for everyone. Small but mighty German beer selection, and the pork belly salad is just incredible. Oh! And Burger Wednesdays!
author: Dan W.

description:
The Biergarten should be a home run in my books because of the great German beer, food, and outdoor space. When the sun is out (and even when it's not), you can bet that people flock to this place to sit out in the sun and drink delicious beer. Biergarten is a great use of space, as they utilize shipping containers and make an empty lot a fun place for people to congregate. Their beer list is extensive and offers something for everything. And the food, omg, I absolutely love German food, and they do not disappoint. My favorite sausages are the Bratwurst and the Currywurst; they are both authentic and filling. The pretzels and pickled deviled eggs are great for sharing (although I hate having to share my pretzel). 

The problem, you ask? That LINE. The line of all lines. In order to get a beer or order food, you have to wait in a line that snakes practically across the lot. And it's not a fast line either, especially when you're thirsty or your friends are already seated and waiting for you. I wish there was a better system for ordering; normally I would just order two drinks at a time, but the beer would quickly get warm sitting in the sun (and no one likes warm beer). So there you have it: a lively spot to meet friends, great beer and food, but the most buzzkill line ever.
author: Regina L.

description: Yummy beer, cute tea lights, nice employees. Fun place!
author: Ayslin R.

description:
One of my favorite places to grab a drink in SF on a sunny day. Pricey but the beers are consistently good. We also had the frankfurter and brat dog with curried potatoes to share. Loved the curried potatoes and the Frankfurter. Didn't love the brat dog. 

Line is super inefficient and painfully slow but service is kind. Seating is all picnic tables so you may sit next to strangers and make a new friend as we did. There were children there so it's kid friendly so which many bars are not.
author: Semuteh F.

description:
I like Hayes Valley. 

I like deviled eggs. 

I like beer.

I love bratwurst (Y'all should know that by now!).

I love the fun environment. 

I love people watching while stuffing my face. 

I don't know how I can walk out of here and still have Smitten's ice cream afterward...

I highly recommend this place for a casual dining. 

I hope you give Biergarten a try. Cheers!
author: Owie N.

description: Pork belly sliders were SO delicious! Also I had a hard cider and it was my new favorite hard cider! I would give it 5 stars because it tasted so good but the 2 mini sliders it came with were $11 + tax so too pricey in my opinion.
author: Jessica B.

description:
Ocktoberfest is in the air!!! My friend chose this this morning and I love German beer gardens so I had to agree! We met at 3pm just 2 hours after they opened and it was already packed! The line wasn't too long maybe like a 5 minute wait and I ordered half a liter of light lager and my friend got a liter of beer along with a side of pretzel and German sausage with potatoes. The pretzel had a nice tingly light salty taste to it; the dough was soft and warm! I was happy that it was freshly baked and it came with radish and mustard- definitely tasted like the pretzel I had from the Frankfurt airport I had a year ago :) Good memories. The German sausage came with a small serving of potatoes. I thought that it would taste amazing with siracha LOL. Coincidentally two German travelers sat next to us and we instantly got along. We asked if it tasted authentically and they actually told us it was really good!! I'd say this beer garden attracts the right crowd- friendly, fun, and adventurous people. The table behind me was definitely enjoying their time due to the sudden increase in volume and laughter! Being here made me want to return to Germany in the winter and I am definitely going to put this thought into consideration since Christmas markets originated from Munich, Germany  


To new visitors or tourists: I highly recommend uberring or bussing here because parking is scarce.
author: Debby L.

description: Cute casual place!! Love the outdoor seating, patio lights, and communal seating. Everyone is super chill - has a really nice vibe going on. Great for a date, group outing, or with a few friends! Staff was friendly also. Didn't have a chance to try the food but it looked and smelled pretty good. I also like the location how its next to a park and kinda in the middle of a street? Oh and having a bar and kitchen built inside shipping containers? Neat!
author: Kim W.

description:
Dear Yelp,

Be careful what you order. Food is delicious but if you're not careful they might give you more food than you intended to order. Check your receipt before paying. Order a pretzel and lemonade soda!
author: Leo V.

description: Great spot in Hayes on a sunny day! Service was wonderful, love to see Emilia there! Definitely recommend coming on Wednesday for the burger
author: Lela R.

description: The Biergarten is a very authentic and fun place to go in Hayes Valley! Especially on a weekend. I went with two friends and I got a beer and a bratwurst. The beer came in a big mug and the bratwurst came with curried potatoes which were very tasty as well as Dijon mustard and minced garlic. The bratwurst was super juicy and melted in your mouth. And the beer was good too!
author: Daniel C.

description:
I stumbled upon this place due to the fact that it's the day after Christmas and souvla was closed, arggg I know!!!  I came here and the setting was really cool and hipster.

The menu was light on entrees, all I got was the light lager that they serve, coolest part is that they only serve half liters and liters, the price was very reasonable, I paid $8 for a half liter.  The beer itself was smooth and on point.

The next time I come I will definitely dine here since I regret not doing so, their menu seems to change regularly and today they offered different types of tacos.  I highly recommend this place to anyone who loves beer, I would make sure I'd go on a day it's not raining since its out in the open.  Can't wait to come back and try one of their 1 liter mugs
author: Josh Giosue D.

description: Probably my favorite beer garden in the city. The outdoor seating is the best part. The beer and food menu is limited but good enough!
author: Hemant J.

description:
3 stars for the great location and for being one of the remarkably few beer gardens in the city.

Minus points because I don't really like the beer selection. Now I'm not a beer expert, but I do have a fully stocked beer fridge in my bedroom so that definitely puts me in  the category of "Someone who drinks a lot of beer" (and a lazy ass, but that's besides the point). The best beers at Biergarten are definitely the darker ones (IPA, amber ale, Oktoberfest, etc.), but on a HOT ass day when I want to be outdoors, I don't want a fucking IPA; I want something lighter and refreshing and those kind of beers here are not my cup of tea. I mean whatever, I'll finish the gargantuan stein of lager because I ain't no lil bitch, but I don't enjoy it. And for $18/Liter, I want to enjoy it.

Another time I was like maybe I'll just drink 2 L of the Radler because it'll taste better and will be the alcohol equivalent of 1 L of its base beer (Helles), but nooope. It was even worse. The added lemon soda is almost chemical tasting and I didn't even get a good buzz :(

It can also get pretty crowded, but what do you expect? Did I mention there are remarkably few beer gardens in the city? Otherwise, on an average "not too hot, not too cold, all you need is a light jacket" day, the other beers will do just fine.
author: Stephanie Joyce D.

description:
Wonderful outdoor seating, and awesomely large liter beers. My boyfriend, his brother, and I visited this place when we were in SF for our usual foodie trips. We waited out in the line before the place even opened, so we got in, ordered, and got seated fairly quickly. I would definitely say this place is not cheap, especially with all that beer - a liter comes out to about $18. 

For food, we got the soft pretzel, currywurst, and pickled things. Overall, all of them were typical bar food, and mostly tasted good in tandem with the beer. I would definitely come back in the future!
author: Monica S.

description:
It's not a Beer Garden, it's the Biergarten -- said some random hipster chick when I asked about this place a few years ago. To be honest, I thought it was gonna be super snotty from her answer and overall appearance from the outside, but was proved wrong and found it to be a very chill place to be with friends. 

I have come here several times during the week and got to say the staff is very nice and the food (a little over priced and small) is good for a pre game or light snack, but shouldn't be your dinner unless you want to spend. Pretty easy and simple concept -- a stand to order beer and food and a set of picnic tables to sit on. The beer selection is kind of small, but still hard to pick from--always ask for a sample bc likely they might not have the beer you usually order as the menu changes. If you are staying there the whole night, I would suggest the ~20 dollar liter of beer, but the half liter seriously does the trick. They only serve beer and wine so go somewhere else if you really want to get turnt. 

What makes this stand out from other beer gardens is that it is purely outdoor (oh the Lights, yes the lights are beautiful) and it is very conveniently located to the freeway and other restaurants. I would highly suggest getting here earlier on weekends or beware the wait/long lines. Very hard to plan things with big groups here as seating is limited, but definitely advise to try this place out. Also, thank you to the staff for giving my friends and I blankets when it gets cold!
author: Eric Joseph D.

description: These guys are a bit too full of themselves given their space and selection. Maybe 6 beers on tap, a shipping container, and some pavement is all you get for your $9 beers. If you want outdoor space it is a good bet, but if you want good beer for reasonable prices there are dozens of better spots in the city.
author: Alek C.

description: Cool spot, good vibes, long lines. If you come on a nice day (especially on the weekend) you're going to have to wait in a bit of a line to place your beer and/or food order. They offer two different sizes for the beer so if you feel like you're gonna want two just go ahead and get the larger size so you don't have to wait in line twice. You might have to wait a little to find a seat at one of the picnic tables too. Once you get a seat you will probably be seated pretty close to your neighbors. Don't come here if you don't like German beer and food since that is what they specialize in. Pretty cool atmosphere to chill at once you manage to get through the line and find a seat.
author: Alissa T.

description: Love this spot! Great outdoor beer garden with lively atmosphere, yummy food (love the deviled eggs!), and blankets in case it gets chilly! I've only been with one other person at a time but I think it would work for large groups too as it's seat yourself in long picnic tables.
author: Ana M.

description: Fun spot to hang out during the day! Just came here with two of my friends and we just had some Aldersbacher draft beer and a pretzel that came with mustard and horse radish. The employees are super nice too! :)
author: Cassandra K.

description: Great atmosphere on a sunny day. Our server Emily was knowledgeable about all of the beers with a great attitude and let us sample.  Will be back!
author: Daniel C.

description:
"Oh look! A long line! It must be good! Should we stand in it?"

The answer is an enthusiastic 'Yes!'

There are many lines you can stand in here in this great city. But if you're a true San Franciscan and really want to stand in line, Biergarten is for you!

You get to stand in line for 40 minutes while you start to suffer from dehydration.
You order 1 Liter of beer because you convince yourself you're that thirsty and you can drink it all.
You chug a third of it and feel better. In fact, you feel GREAT.
Then your pretzel comes out and you eat it so fast, you look around to decide who'd want to perform the Heimlich Maneuver when the inevitable choking will happen.
You don't choke and you're still alive. But now you're so thirsty from all the salt you chug another third of your beer. You feel OK.
You look around and have an epiphany over whether this is what life is all about.
You decide that it is and you attempt to drink the last third of your beer.
You almost throw up.

Your friends are convinced that you did throw up.

Whatever. They don't understand. They drag out out and take you home.

You feel great.
author: Lanie L.

description: Good beer, good food, relaxed atmosphere, good crowd, decent prices The line does get long, but worth it. It's become my 1st stop after the flight in from NY to grab a beer have a light snack before getting my vaca started. There is a little park across the street, which is closed to traffic, and its in Hayes Valley a great neighborhood filled with great restaurants, bakeries, other goodies and cute shops. I love Biergarten!!!
author: Karen R.

description: German beer garden? I don't think so. The sausages were kind of watery. I'm not sure how this is even possible but that was gross. The Curry Wurst was also not really got. I definitely wouldn't recommend any food there.
author: Henry S.

description: I don't know if I would even consider this a "beer garden."  More of just some picnic tables set up in between hipster central of smitten ice cream and blue bottle coffee.  Only 4 or so beers on draft ($8 +) and one white, one red wine option.  A bit overpriced and nothing too exciting.  I think there are better patio + beer + food combos in the area for a better price.
author: Kelsey B.

description:
It is what it sounds like - an outdoor area (no indoor space) with picnic tables, cute lighting, and BEER. A half liter for their 4 draft beers was $9, and a full liter in a stein was $18. 

I enjoyed the vivacious yet laidback atmosphere, but that crazy line that came with it--not so much. I think my group stayed at the same table for about 3 hours and each time I snuck a peek back at the line, it never got any shorter! On a weekend, I'd say expect to wait at least 30 minutes to order your food and drink.

That's the price you pay for doing something that everyone else wants to do in SF I GUESS! 

Other tips:
-- They don't allow you to move their tables around even though they're oriented somewhat awkwardly. I saw multiple groups getting told off for attempting to shift their tables..
-- Grab a blanket if it gets cold!

All in all, good vibes & clean bathrooms, but I'd appreciate more beers on draft and a faster moving line!!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Why do I listen to my boyfriend and not verify everything he says? I claims he had been here before and dogs were allowed. I showed up with our little chug and we were asked to tie her outside. So we did. Although- the reason I even wanted to come here was because I thought it was dog friendly.
Anyways we tied up my dog, ordered and then walked around for 10m trying to find somewhere to sit. And we needed to sit somewhere close to my dog who kind of has anxiety and also is cute enough to be kidnapped. I think. Profiling people that might leave soon didn't work because people just stuck around after their drinks and food were done. 
Coming here was a good experience but I probably would plan better next time. Come early to get a spot. And don't bring your dogs.
author: Julianna I.

description:
3.5 stars

On a sunny day, this is a great place to escape to and people watch. It's very minimal (small fenced in area with some benches and tables) but there is usually always a line to purchase beer/food. There are long picnic tables and benches to sit down with your beer (good selection but only sell 0.5 or 1L). Beer is good, food is average. Seems like they almost want to promote turnover since the barrier to getting a 2nd drink is pretty high (would have to get back in line). We would've liked to stay longer and get another beer but was not in the mood to stand back in line for another 20-30 min.
author: Yin H.

description:
Love this Biergarten!! I really enjoy the outdoor seatings and the decorations. It's pretty much first come first serve and great way to meet people! (Since we have to share the long tables). 

I wish they had more food options and great beer selections. The burger slider was really good and the picked devilled eggs! You have the options to order half liter or a full liter. Definitely a great place to enjoy food and beer.
author: Jenn L.

description:
Nice beergarden

This place seems to always have a long line, and for good reason--the vibe is really chill and the beer is good! Need you ask more?

Located literally in a park on the road, this place is hard to visit. The opening hours are very restrictive (2pm to 8pm for an alcohol place? that's crazy, like having a brunch place open at night!). We were there before the 2pm opening time and there was already a line waiting outside the gate. Wooot

Once the place opened, the inside was packed. All the benches were filled with people, and there was still a line outside. Even though there's a lot of folks in the house, the place is chill--folks everywhere are chatting, sipping beers, laughing, having a good time.

In terms of beer quality, the drinks are solid. You can get a large cup of 1L beer--nice. I got the brass monkey, which was a OJ mixed beer--pretty orangy :) Definitely recommend going for the 1L cup if you have a chance.

Will definitely visit again if I can somehow be there during opening hours!
author: Henry L.

description: The beer is good and served liter of half liter. The snacks I've tried were pretty good too. Nothing you would go out of your way to eat. It's clearly for when you want to sit outside in the sunny Hayes valley and drink some beer. The picnic tables are rickety and unstable and smashed together. It's all communal style seating. There is one small area with covering if you want toms shade
author: Piper W.

description:
I love this place for so many reasons.  I only wish they could stay open later, but I'm guessing it must be a noise issue considering this place is completely outdoors (aside from the shipping containers).  The Biergarten is a really cool spot located in Hayes Valley.  It's perfect for the warmer summertime, but they do open in the winter.  Look for the blankets if you're cold!  

They serve beer here (obviously) in giant steins which is a lot of fun.  They also have a pretty well-sized menu full of German food!  I really love their purple deviled eggs as well as and of their sausages.  It's all great and the vibe of this place is just a ton of fun.  

Also props to the employees here for basically serving us right around closing.  I felt bad coming in so late, but it's really tough to stop by here considering how early they close.  Thank you for serving us and making it a great night!
author: Bryson L.

description: Cute outdoor venue near park with amazing pork sliders but warm beer.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
It's a decent spot to hang out when the weather permits. When it doesn't and Karl is out in full force, they give out blankets. Although I wouldn't really want to use them because let's be real here, how often do they wash them? 

Decently priced beers. Pretzel wasn't that great, but pickled devil eggs were amazing. 

Sometimes there's a long arse line to get in. When that's the case it's not really worth waiting. 

The crowd seems fairly mixed, although there's an occasional genius who will bring their toddler in with them and give me evil side eye just because I dropped an F bomb. Seriously, who the heck brings kids into bars? Stop doing that. Hayes Valley people, I swear.
author: Susy C.

description: Really cool place to go on a hot day. It's usually the first place I think of to go in the city. The radler is what I recommend here. The downside of the place is that it can get crowded and the lines can get pretty long.
author: Nick Y.

description:
There's nothing like spending a lazy Sunday afternoon playing drinking games with friends. Biergarten is the perfect venue for such an occasion. A fenced in open area bar right in Hayes Valley, this place has a very chill vibe to it. The beer selection here is decent enough and they have some really massive mugs you can order them in, which worked out perfectly for our intended activities. 

Another reason I had been looking forward to coming here is that they had also made a top 100 7x7 list recently for their pretzels. We ordered an assortment of them, and although the plain one was the one that had made the list, both the crispy pork version and the banana dessert option were far better. All of them had great texture and crispy outsides. The plain one came with a pile of minced garlic and a mustard that had entirely too much horseradish in it. Why the plain one made the list instead of the others is beyond me. 

Another cool part of this place is that they have lots of blankets to use for anyone who wants to use them. Definitely considerate of them, especially with how chilly it can get in Hayes Valley on a cold night. 

Overall, Biergarten is a great place to have some beers and snacks in a comfortable open area. So far of the few I've been to in SF, it's the one I like best. For this purpose I'm going to say that Biergarten is "as good as it gets."
author: Mark O.

description: Had to wait in a pretty long line to order drinks and food, but it was decently quick of a wait. Because larger groups send a friend to reserve table space, its harder for smaller groups to get a table once they have waited and ordered. Food is good, pretzels are delicious.
author: Samantha E.

description:
One of my favourite places in Hayes Valley especially when it's not too cold outside.

They have half litre and 1 litre jugs of beers, for $8-9 and $15-16 respectively. The selection of beers is quite good.

The place has large picnic-style benches. If you go on warm evenings it can get pretty crowded, but usually you should be able to find a spot.

They also have some snacks, such as pretzels, pretzel knots, deviled eggs. I thought the pretzels were fantastic! 

I love the place overall, though wish they had heating lamps - that would make it an all-year around spot for me, as opposed to just a summer spot.
author: Tanay J.

description: Although it's a bit pricey, I really liked the environment as well as the food and beer selection! Their beers are HUGE. The deviled eggs are purple and just okay - could be more flavorful. The pork belly sliders on the other hand are AMAZING - you have to get them!
author: Lane G.

description: Sweet place for beer outdoors. All ages so we took our daughter who loved the pretzels and sausages. Great beer in 1/2 liters and liters. Don't let the "not good for all ages" deter you. We had fun in the sun...though as it's SF it's mostly cold. Wear layers.
author: Debey G.

description: I've been to several different biergarten and let me tell you this one really disappointed me. It is not decorated nice, they don't have a lot of beer selection. The food is good and the prices are fair overall. I expected a little more from this place, I stayed there for about an hour to finish my food and drink and after that I left because it was pretty boring and it did not feel like a biergarten. If you've never been to one this will be an ok place to go to
author: Adriana A.

description:
A pretty darn perfect place to hang out with friends - or just the people nearby - on any given "nice" day (or night). 

The beer - giant. I'd like more of a variety, but admittedly I'm a girly beer drinker. Still, there's something so satisfying about drinking out of a beer stein the size of your head, with some good heft to it.

The snacks - exactly right. What goes better with a giant beer than a giant pretzel? Or, really good, pickled deviled eggs? #recommended 

The atmosphere - picnic tables, string lighting, the heart of Hayes Valley. Worth spending some time.
author: Catie F.

description: I'm not into beers but this was a nice place to hang out on a sunny SF Sunday. I ordered a cider which was pretty good and the date ordered a wine which seemed to be good. It's definitely a good place to enjoy the sun and hang out casually. They have long tables so you end up sharing it with other groups but once you're drinking you don't really notice. I was really surprised that the bathroom didn't have mirrors but I guess I'm the only vain human who cared. I really was not a fan of the cashier/bartender but the service staff were really nice. I would give this a 2nd date spot. I think sharing tables with strangers would be a bit intimidating for me. But I get scared easily...so, go ahead and bring a first date.
author: Pawanpreet G.

description: Biergarten gets the stamp of approval from my Bavarian boyfriend, which says a lot.  The requisite tree is in the center of the garten and additional vegetation is planted around the perimeter so it feels more green even though you're in the middle of a city.  The benches are exactly the ones they have in Bavaria (though they are spaced slightly further apart here since we Americans need our personal space).  We didn't try the food but I noticed they serve pretzels with obatzda, a cream cheese and paprika spread, which is surprisingly legit.  And of course the German beer list is solid (got your weissbier, lager, doppelbock, pilsner, and even a radler (50/50 Helles lager + sparkling lemonade) - but it's sold at American prices.  A half liter will cost you $8-10 (Schneider Weisse is $9 and their Edel-Weisse is $10), and a full liter costs double - so no cost savings for ordering the liter.  Besides the prices, the other thing that is very un-Bavarian is the line.  Germans hate lines and they really hate having to wait for their beer.  At Biergarten on a sunny Sunday afternoon we waited 27 minutes to order because well, San Franciscans love lines.  However the SF touch that I do appreciate is the blankets for when it inevitably gets cold and windy.  All in all, Biergarten is a very smartly executed concept which is why we continue to return.  But as my boyfriend says, be prepared to just close your eyes and swipe the card!
author: Beatrice W.

description:
A beautiful spot with reminiscence of actual German biergarten. Number of beer taps are just enough, food is awesome. 

Plus I just felt it was end of the keg and informed the crew and they brought me beer from a fresh keg even if I didnot ask for one.

I'd just advise them to play some German music time to time and create a more familiar atmosphere
author: Koray Kaan Ö.

description: Thet have the best pork.belly sliders ive ever tried . That day me and my friends went here got kind of cold and windy and wouldnt you know it , the staff has blankets neatly folded for customers to.use so instead of us hurrying up to eat and drink we ended up staying another hour for more food and drinks cozy in our blankets :)
author: Louise B.

description:
A bit pricey but it's a great place to kick it with a few good friends. 

I wanted to hang out with a good friend of mine and celebrate the end of her exams. We wanted to go somewhere with alcohol. Somewhere in the city. She then stumbled upon an article on Thrillist that mentioned something about beer served by the liter...and that's how I found myself at Biergarten. 

We thought we arrived early. To our surprise, there was already a pretty substantial line of hipsters and it was a bit of a wait to find a seat. 

Admittedly, I'm not exactly a fan of most of the beers they serve here (more of a fan of American craft beers), but considering the venue, I wouldn't want to drink anything other than German beer. They do have a limited tap list. You can probably find something you'll like, though. As for me, I was really looking forward to drinking a dunkel (dark lager) since I haven't had a dunkel beer in a while, but they were out. Ended up with a liter of Schneider-Weisse ($16) which was okay. My friend and I also split the pork belly sliders ($9). The bread was fluffy, buttery, and nicely done. I really am a stickler when it comes to choosing the right bread for a sandwich and Biergarten did it right! The pork was tender and pretty flavorful. I liked that red cabbage slaw too. Overall, it was a great slider but not very filling for the price. 

As for the seats, unless you are in a large group, you're probably going to be sharing one of those tables with a group of strangers. 

Oh. And if you want another beer or more food, you'll have to fall back in line...which wouldn't be that big of a deal if the lines weren't so long. 

Anyway, this place is pretty cool. I'll definitely come back for another liter and maybe one of those delicious looking prezels since the weather is nice right now.  If you're interested in getting some small german bites with large steins of german beer and  don't mind waiting in line or paying high prices, then I recommend that you stop by sometime!
author: John B.

description: Makes me think I am back in Germany - join some strangers and share a giant beer in the sunshine - nothing gets better than that.  Friendly atmosphere, and line moved quickly!
author: Margo B.

description:
A nice big space but line to order is quite long. 

And not much shade so beware of sunburn on very sunny days.

Food is good. Its a very popular place, I guess thats why theres no motivation to move the line faster.
author: Philip L.

description:
This place was created for sunny San Francisco days. Benches are strewn across the open space, so come here with at least one friend so someone can fetch seats while the other orders food and beer. I've only tried the beer and not the food, but those purple deviled eggs look tasty!

There is a limited number of options for beer, but they're all good, so they don't need more options. They do have two sizes of mugs, depending on how ambitious you're feeling. The bartenders are super nice, and the social atmosphere of the whole place just makes this the perfect location for being lazy and enjoying some ice cold beers.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
This place is so cool! I've always seen it and have wanted to stop in for a drink but now that I actually have, I will definitely be returning. 

I went on a Thursday night with some co workers, not expecting to have too grand of a time. But it turned out to be so great! Just the atmosphere of things was awesome, everyone of the customers seemed like they were genuinely having a good time and would like to chat with you, kind of a Portland feel!

The venue itself was super cute with tables to share and sit with others and like at festivals. The lighting wasn't too dim at night with their string lights, was just perfect!

Although the beer selection isn't too large, it was really good! Tried multiple and they had a lot of good german beers, for a good price! The food was Great. Authentic and very tastey! Bratwurst was great!!

Now they don't get 4 stars because of two things, the employees weren't too kind, kind of grumps to be honest, and it got really cold! They should get heating lamps! But they did have blankets, which is nice... But what if the person before had lice?! 

Either way, I'll definitely go back.
author: Elysia M.

description: This is in one of my favorite hangout areas in the city. The ambience is excellent. There is always a steady line for the beer. There are several good choices daily. I got a red ale westfalia. It was delicious. The bratwurst and the deviled eggs were quite good too. Can't wait to go back.
author: Niloy B.

description: Love this place! It's in a great location in Hayes Valley in walking distance of other bars and restaurants, including Smitten ice cream next door. They sell a few finger foods here (sliders, warm pretzels, sausage, etc) to enjoy with your beer. I like that the selection of beers isn't too overwhelming and the menu at the counter tells you the alcohol percentage in each. The "building" is made out of recycled storage units. I appreciate the community seating.
author: Natasha K.

description: This is the place to go if you're a fan of German food, beer, and, of course, the Bavarian-style liter mugs. YES. SO MUCH YES. Their menu caters to veg heads just as much as they do to meat lovers. SCORE! And, they serve non-wheat beers/ hard ciders, too. WINNING all around. PROST!
author: Flor K.

description:
Prost to Germany, German beer and German food!

Biergarten is exactly what I have been searching for and I need to make sure that I come here more often. Located in the heart of Hayes Valley, this beautiful industrial-inspired beer garden, is certainly a go-to spot for beer lovers looking to enjoy one of the few outdoor patios that San Francisco has to offer.

The menu includes all your classic German wants (nay, needs), including pretzels, curry wurst pickles and more! For beer, you have anything from a light blonde, to a dark amber. They've got stiegl, franziskaner, schneiderweisse and even radler (beer/sprite mix). And don't worry, if the German food and German beer isn't enough German for you, you can always order your drink in a classic (and massive) German beer mug. 

The garden has plenty of seating, so don't worry about that. However, the place is serve yourself, so you might need to wait in line to order. If it's a beautiful day and you want to get outside, I highly suggest coming to Biergarten for at least a pint or two.
author: Aletta B.

description: Outdoor seating is pretty neat. They have a small selection of food that will definitely fill you up. They close a little early evening, but other than that, it's a nice little spot when it's not too windy or cool outside.
author: Leo M.

description: The outside setting is fantastic, the beer selection is somewhat limited - I'm still a big Toronado fan - and the prices are just outrageous. Highly overpriced for what you get.
author: Gia R.

description:
I organized a happy hour for an alum group I volunteer for here.  It gets crowded when the weather's nice out,  so come before 3 or get ready to wait in line ~40-60 minutes for food + beer. 

It's a nice, relaxing spot to relax with a stein (is that how you spell that?) and some friends on a sunny day though and people are really friendly. The tables seat ~8 so you'll likely end up sharing with strangers. 

Tip: bring sunglasses and sunscreen. It's easy to lose track of time and get sunburnt here.
author: Sophie B.

description: So this review might be more helpful if I remembered what everyone's beers were called but the authentic German names combined with the beer buzz are contributing to the uncertainty. I had the edelweiss, that much I remember, and it was delicious! Everyone in the group got the larger size, and let me just say for someone who is 5'2" this is a lot of beer. It took some serious will power to finish. Thankfully the beer was amazing and extremely smooth so it was an enjoyable hour of trying to finish the mug he size of my head (probably bigger). The weather was amazing in SF this weekend and coming out to the Biergarten with some pals made for a great afternoon. We stayed into the evening and the staff is so friendly and sweet that they gave some of us girls in shorts blankets to stay warm. Overall great experience and can't wait to come back.
author: Shruti S.

description: It was a little chilly on a Wednesday afternoon here (I wish they would have heat lamps for these occasions), but we were really happy with the beer selection (I got local beer Fort Point), plus they have yummy food. I had the yummy pork belly slider (big chunk of pork belly, sorry no pic as I was starved and ravaged it), and my friends had the burger and hot dog - both were enjoyed!  Chilly, but otherwise, quite happy!
author: Maile N.

description:
I love the concept of ordering up a round of beer and enjoying it in an outdoor's patio environment on a sunny, cool day.

Dine over beer - it is simple and relaxing.

They have a variety of beer selections and there are many picnic tables to lounge at with a group or two.  

They provide side snacks, such as pretzels and salads, if you feel like you need something to munch on with their well-flavored beer.  Otherwise, a liter of beer is all good by itself.

Biergarten is purely a delight for recreational and leisurely purposes!
author: Tiffany D.

description: Went on a Friday afternoon and it was overly crowded with tech bros. Food and beer was good.
author: Joseph M.

description:
This place is a great hangout spot with friends or a date, right next to smitten' ice cream too! The only downside is that it closes at 8pm, which makes it challenging if you're trying to get a beer after work. Their beer selection is small but worthwhile. 

The food is really great here, pork belly sliders are amazing and burger is super flavorful too.
author: Anna C.

description: Always a good time at this place.  Why doesn't San Francisco have more outdoor places like this???
author: Charles C.

description: Came here on a Sunday afternoon. Loved it! The beer and food are served out of shipping containers and they have a bunch of picnic tables set up outside that you can sit at. Laid back atmosphere, great spot to hang out on a sunny day and drink a few beers. Seems like seating can be a problem but most people were willing to slide down and share their picnic table. Great spot for day dri
author: Melissa H.

description:
Biergarten is a perfect place to go during the day when the sun is out. It gets cold and breezy when the sun goes down, and they do have blankets (which is a nice touch!), but it is outdoors so there's that. 

The beer mixers are delicious! I love the lemon soda/beer combo, and their food selection is solid German street food. However, the line does get long, so beat the rush by coming at an earlier than usual lunch time.
author: Leeyen R.

description:
Biked here with a friend one day, and was ready for some food and drinks. 

We got in line, which wasn't very long. Just enough time to decide on some food and drinks. 

+ They have one of my favourite beers on tap! Schineider Nelson Sauvin. It's an amazing beer with a nice floral-esque nose AND flavour to it. I ended up getting two of these.
+ The food was decent. Better than average, but not amazing. The prices were reasonable, not that expensive, and accurately reflected the value food. 
++ We got pork belly sliders, deviled eggs, and a pretzel. They were all fairly delicious. The deviled eggs are pink!

When we went up for round two of beers, the queue was fairly long and it was quite a wait. Seating is definitely hard. They have plenty of seats, but this place gets packed and popular!

I cannot comment on parking because I biked. 
There is no real "service" happening here. You buy your beer and then you sit down. Food is brought to you, and your tables bused. Very little interaction, so we'll keep that neutral. It's actually better that way so you can quality time talking with friends without being interrupted. 

Good beers, decent food, reasonable prices. Will return when they come back from vacation, and I recommend this place!
author: Kaje Y.

description: Long lines but worth the wait. I especially love the salad basket with the beet salad being my favorite. Also, don't miss out on the fresh pretzels. The beer is all German style, so it's fruity, not hoppy. This is my favorite place to be on a rare hot SF day.
author: Adriana A.

description:
Had a friend come up into the city with her cousin and wanted to grab dinner elsewhere, but it was packed, so we walked around Hayes Valley for a little bit. They decided on the Biergarten since they wanted sausage ;)

It was cold, but it wasn't too bad for me since I'm used to SF weather now, but my friend from Socal was FREEZING. The owners or people who worked there found many blankets for them to stay warm. They ended up having two or three blankets to stay warm. 

I ended up getting the pretzel and pork belly sliders. The pretzel was okay. It was cold by the time I got it, so it wasn't amazing. I also didn't get a beer (since I don't really like beer) with it so probably didn't have the full experience with the pretzel I was supposed to. The pork belly sliders, on the other hand, were amazing. The pickles and the sauce that came with the thickly cut belly was so good. 

Overall, great food and good service. 

Protip: blankets to stay warm! Steal them. Also, that pork belly!
author: Nina Y.

description: Love this place. The energy is really great. Such a nice outdoor space to hang out with friends or peeps from office - a great place for some great beer, pickles, pretzels and sausages. Good fun! Have been here already twice and will be back. It can get bit cold after sunset so bring a jacket! It is usually pretty packed even on weekdays so be prepared to spend few minutes in line to order. Love the community benches!
author: Heliana M.

description:
Coming here definitely made my friends and I reminisce about our recent time studying abroad in Germany. Though it was certainly a different experience, I think this place did a pretty accurate job in replicating the atmosphere of a typical German Biergarten. More so like ones you might see in Berlin with it's industrial urban feel. 

The beer was good, slightly more expensive that we were used to, but can't complain too much about that since we were used to buying beer for 3 Euros a pop in Germany. So...bad comparison. One suggestion I might make is maybe add some fries to the menu? Currywurst just isn't the same without some pommes. Other than that this is a great place to drink, hang out and catch up with friends.
author: Vicki L.

description:
Beer gardens are down right awesome. If I lived in SF, I'd come here every weekend with friends!

They had a good selection of beer and food. I wanted a light beer so I ordered the Radler (half Lager, half Lemon soda). I really enjoyed it and would get it again! My friend got the Schneider Weisse which was also good. In terms of food we got the Pork Belly Sliders and Meat Knot (pretzel and pastrami) which were both delicious! 

Blankets are also provided for when it gets too chilly. How accommodating is that!
author: Kathy L.

description:
After one set of friends left us for the day, we came here with a couple of other friends to continue catching up and trying out places in the city. One friend was meeting up with some other friends here as they were celebrating a birthday. So it was fun to come along.

By the time we ended up here we were hungry. So we decided to order a bit of food. Unfortunately, they seem to run out of the good stuff early (like pretzels? annoying). So we ordered the curry wurst, pretzel dumplings and the beet salad. I'm pretty sure we ordered something else as well, but the drunken haze I was in makes it hard to remember. We also got 1 L steins of beer. Unfortunately, like other German beer places in town, you can't get boots, but it was a nice substitute. 

They do provide blankets for when it gets cold at night, so we huddled up in the warmth of the blankets and drank our beer and ate our food. The food was okay. Nothing super amazing, but fairly standard. The curry wurst definitely didn't hold up to the one I had in Germany, but I wasn't that surprised. The beet salad was nice. 

It's a fun place to hang out and sit outdoors and drink, but it's not incredibly impressive, as ultimately it's just a fenced in area on a bit of cement.
author: Grant T.

description: Who couldn't love this place?  Great pretzels, good beer and you get to sit outside!  About as close to a real German beer garden in SF that you'll get.  German culture is more fun than the avg American thinks . . . Just sayin'.
author: Charlotte M.

description: Must get their Fort Point red ale beer! And upgrade to the 1 Liter. We shared with 3 ppl.
author: Erville V.

description:
Zehr Gut!!!
Excellent place right in the middle of SF with the feel of the original biergartens in Germany! 0.5L & 1L mugs of draft.. (of course, the review is not biased cos of that... ;) :P )
They had 4 different beers on draft ranging from a Helles to a Dopplebock and then a few bottles and also housemade mulled wine. 8$ for the 0.5L and $16 for the 1L mug of helles, obviously I had to get the larger mug. :) 
There's not a lot of seating and its picnic style shared benches. So late in the afternoon, seating wasn't an issue. But it does get busy at times and the line to order food goes out on the street. Also FYI, they did not have propane heaters. So once the sun goes down, be ready to bring on those jackets.
The food options are pretty good. Got a pretzel and a bratwurst. Bratwurst came with curry potatoes, dark mustard and horseradish. Was excellent with beer. They also have pretzel knots and deviled eggs. Probably will try those next time.
Wish they opened a bit earlier and added some heater after sun down! Taking a star down for that, otherwise this was a definite 5 star!!! Definitely coming back again!
author: Vikram C.

description:
A friend and I shared the Bratswurst basket. The Bratwurst was delicious, but I wish that it came with more potatoes, because it was a bit hard to eat one whole Bratwurst all on its own without anything else to balance out the taste of meat. The potatoes that the basket did come with were super tasty, and was coated in a very delicious sauce. 

We came in during the evening, and the ambience out here is very fun and cheerful. Since San Francisco experiences many cold nights, there are large warm blankets available for people to wrap themselves into or use to cover their legs. I would love to try this place out again during the afternoon, and try more food here next time.
author: Lydia T.

description:
Here in SF, we love drinking, the outdoors, and waiting in line. So why not line up to get into the biergarten in the center of the city?

Good selection of beer on tap (and wine). The trick is to send people to wait in the beer line while others stake out tables; just make sure the beer-buyers have everyone's IDs. Food's pretty good, a smattering of sausages, pretzels and other German bar bites, but it's no Suppenkuche (their must-try sister restaurant down the street). They seem to be super chill about you bringing stuff in too, like coffee from blue bottle or ice cream from smitten...
