It's beautiful when the sun goes down and the hanging lights start twinkling, but it gets COLD. They have some heavy blankets but you should come prepared anyway. Also, there is just the 2 restrooms which always feel like a failure in design for a place serving beer by the liter to the masses.
author: Vivian H.

description: Real folksy German beer culture in the middle of the city! You gotta to be incredibly lucky to find parking nearby. But its a spot worth a Uber trip any day.
author: J M.

description: A great place to spend an evening with friend. A large outdoor urban/industrial seating area and friendly service. It gets cold and windy in the city but Biergarten kindly offers blankets to wrap yourself in while sipping on a beer on their picnic benches. I was a fan of their Hefeweizen which came out to $18 for 1 L. If you come here, you absolutely must try their pickled deviled eggs. I was initially attracted/ (slightly scared?) by their vibrant pink color. I mean eggs shouldn't be bright pink right? Well, it didn't matter because those were some DELICIOUS deviled eggs. Seriously, try them. Only qualm was that why close so early--9pm! Will definitely come back again!
author: Naveena S.

description: Went on a warm Friday night and loved the ambience here. The vibe is super chill and relaxed and a great place to come with a group of friends. Its slightly difficult to find an open bench to sit at but you just have to swoop when you see one. A little on the pricey side for food and beer too but definitely worth it for the experience.
author: Lexi H.

description:
On an ideal sunny day in SF, this is where I would be. I ALWAYS get the full liter beers so I don't have to get back in line (the lines can get pretty crazy)  to get a second one. I also always get a pretzel or two, not only are they nice and warm, but help to soak up all that beer. One thing about this place is that all the patrons are incredibly friendly. I don't know if it's the communal seating, but every time I come here I end up meeting someone new an have played games with other groups sitting at our table. 

I have never had a beer I didn't like here. I generally stick to the lighter stuff since I'm usually under the sun. Ordering can be a bit overwhelming if you don't know your German beers. The cool thing is they let you sample different beers before you get it and generally give good recommendations if you ask. If you are there later, they give you blankets which I thought was pretty cool. This is undeniably one of my favorite places in SF!
author: Thielson D.

description: Fun atmosphere, exactly what it says, a beer garden.  Picnic tables shared with other folks, outside.  They serve a variety of german-style beers (no IPA) and things like sausage, sliders, and pretzels.  Only tried the beer, and let us try a couple before we ordered.  The line was crazy when we arrived and the tables pretty full, but we found a spot to sit for two with no problem.  It was overcast, so we asked for a blanket (they have a bunch of wool blankets for you).
author: Jennifer C.

description: Great place to grab a liter (or two) of some fantastic beers. Also a variety of German pub grub, including deviled eggs, sauerkraut, pretzels, etc. Several large tables as outdoor seating. Especially nice on sunny days in SF.
author: Will H.

description:
Super soft bloody beef, topped with some snappy rocket. Brioche buns are the way to my heart, but the thing that really did it for me: deep fried onions. Thank the Lord. 
As far as Biergartens go, this place is totally unauthentic and the prices are bordering on the clinically insane. However, it is a great place to hang out and I would recommend it to anyone in the area.
author: Andrea F.

description: I ethically and morally cannot give any less than five stars to a bar that serves perfect German beer, in steins, on a sunny patio, with pretzels and sausages available as needed. There are piles of blankets if it gets chilly, and lots of UV rays for those of us who are vitamin D deprived.
author: Tasha D.

description:
Big sister Suppenkuche serves traditional German food and a good selection of alcohol. Like older siblings, Suppenkuche has that confidence that no one tries to mess with. And it shows because there's always a line! (Minimum wait on a Saturday night is 1 hour.) They've perfected keeping people happy, and you can tell with the solid four star rating with 2,500 reviews!

Little sister Biergarten is a little similar, yet has its own flair. (Younger siblings were always a little more rebellious, right?) It's outdoors and fenced around. Pro-tip: you order the food and beer, and your friend grabs a table. When the weather is nice, you bet all the tables are taken! 

- Beers come in half liters or liters. Go big or go home!
- Food was good and reasonably priced. The pork belly sliders were yummy!
- No "real" service - they bring out your food and clear the table.
- There's a park right in front, and Smitten is just around the corner.
- Wed-Sat 2-8pm. Sun 1-7pm.

This place is just like a little sister - carefree, easy going, and fun! Cheers!
author: Christine S.

description: Service is slow as shit but the beer is ok. This is now just filler so yelp will leave me alone about the length of my review.
author: Mark T.

description: The beer rocks here and so do the ladies that run this kick ass joint! Had a great time and enjoyed my wheat brew!
author: Jessica W.

description:
Came here on a sunny Sunday afternoon with a group of girlfriends ready to get our chill & drank on. You order at the counter and grab one of their picnic tables outside. Apparently its hard to get a table, but we came around 1:30pm and there were many tables available. So come right when they open if you don't want to wait for seating! They don't allow pets (unfortunately), but I explained that my little Maltese was a service dog and they allowed him in under the condition that he stays leashed and on the ground the entire time and not on the tables. Fair enough! Thanks Biergarten for being understanding :) 

I had the frankfurter and the cider since I'm not a beer drinker. The frankfurter was delicious and came with a generous serving of sauerkraut. I'm not usually a fan of sauerkraut but I found it to be delicious! The cider was not too dry and not too sweet, perfect in my opinion.

The service is prompt, the prices are reasonable, and the beer and food options are vast and tasty! We had the deviled eggs, the brat basket, and the gnome burger- everything was delicious. Biergarten is a gem in Hayes Valley and a place that me and my friends will come hang out on the weekends.
author: Erica L.

description:
Great place with an energetic atmosphere. Be sure to get there early so a friend can snag a communal table while you wait in line to get your (liter of) beer. Also have everyone's ID in your hand when you go get drinks; it's required. All the beers are yummy and the food is to die for. I recommend ordering the Weihenstephaner Original Lager, Bratwurst and the Pork Belly sliders.

Biergarten also has a sister restaurant called Suppenküche that you should go check out!
author: Shannon R.

description:
Yay for Biergarten. 

+ good beer
+ nice space
+ blankets when it's chilly outside (pretty much always)
+ beet salad = SO GOOD
+ pretzels 
+ deviled eggs are beautiful
author: Reese A.

description: Yum! Very good selection of beers and the food was tasty too. Great weekend afternoon spot in the city
author: Jonathan H.

description: YUM! I ordered the bratdog and the light lager beer and they were both scrumptious! Also, I was a fan that they allowed us in even though they were already doing last calls! They also provide blankets if you ask for it! Definitely going to come back to try the rest of the food and beers and relax!
author: Cynthia L.

description:
Summary:
3.5 stars because the beer was great but holy crap, i waited in line for an hour for it!! and then had to wait for a table. what is this?! disneyland? no. didn't come to wait in lines all day. I would go again if my friends really wanted to go cuz the beer was good. But the lines are no bueno.

Food:
I had the golden wheat beer and it was really good. I liked it a lot. plus it was bigger than my head!! Paid $18 for a 1L beer in a big glass. That lasted me a while. But I'm not a fast drinker, friends had about the same though. My friends ordered the mushroom sliders which I got a bite of and it was pretty good, however it was $9 for two small sliders. A teensy bit pricey for not having any meat in 'em.

Atmosphere: 
so basically this place is a chain-gated off area, and inside are two bungalows (1 to make the food and another to serve the beer) and a bunch of wooden tables with bench and a couple of string lights. I wish it didn't have the gates, it'd feel a lot better. It has such a chill vibe cuz everyones just having a good time cuz everyone's drinking. But if you think about it, they didn't put that much effort into making the place look very nice.  Also people just sit forever and never leave so be prepared to wait for a table! 

Service:
Pretty clean tables. Some staff come around from time to time. They don't clear tables right away but they did it within about 10 minutes of my friends and I sitting down. You wait in line and order, and you take a number and they deliver your food.
author: Tiffany L.

description: Great place for a cold brew and delicious bites! We had the pickled deviled eggs and pork sliders. Sooo good!
author: Jimena O.

description:
Biergarten is a great spot if you want to have drinks while enjoying the warm weather outside. If you are hosting your underage younger sibling from out of town, this is the perfect place because they don't ID until you buy a beer! So they can sit, hang out, eat food, and not feel guilty for severely limiting everyone's activities.

"Garden" is a stretch of a description, but it is a concrete garden smack dab in the middle of the city, with open seating and picnic tables blocked off by a chain link fence. The surrounding area (Hayes Valley) is fantastic, with many great options for dinner or brunch, cute clothing shops and dessert stores, and there is an actual green park area just across the street. Right now they have a giant wooden temple and an art wall there too, and sometimes there are pop-up markets, so walking around can be fun.

Pro-tips:
1. Go early to snag a table -- they are hard to get. Don't be surprised if you end up sharing one with strangers.
2. If you are meeting friends, the line is just for food/beer, not to get inside.
3. If you're unsure about the weather, dress warm -- it's often chilly, and you'll be outside the whole time. There are no heat lamps, but they do have blankets in the storage container.
4. Their beers are great and can come in giant glasses! I also liked the Pork Belly Sliders (9).
author: Cynthia W.

description:
I visited the Biergarten when I was in town catching up with friends and loved my experience! Located about a block away from where I was staying, it was a cool outdoor space with beer taps flowing in an updated and renovated shipping container. There are a few staff members behind the bar checking IDs, pouring drinks, and making great food recommendations.

There is plenty of fenced in patio space and dogs are welcome to look on from designated areas outside. Long park style benches and tables allow for gatherings large and small to meet up and it gave a super friendly vibe. Our group mixed with those sharing the table with us and made a few new friends in the process (how can you not over great beer?). 

They offer liter and half-liter pours of about 10 on tap selections. They have a solid bar food menu (which I didn't sample this trip) but smelled incredible. Christmas lights add to the ambiance in the evenings and they even have blankets you can use for chilly nights. I recommend stopping by for after work specials and snacks!
author: Kate M.

description: I love Biergarten and so has everyone I've brought here. I also like the concept of reusing old shipping containers and turning them into this beer garden. Every time I'm here I must get the deviled eggs. A few other items I recommend are the pork belly sliders, the bratwurst platter, pretzel and the gnome burger. The curry potatoes that accompany the bratwurst are great. They have good German beer! Outdoor communal seating allows for socialization amongst other patrons. I said it once and I'll say it again, I love Biergarten.
author: Kristina S.

description:
With limited options for drinking beer outside in San Francisco, the Biergarten delivers and delights.  Tough to beat on a nice, sunny day.

The small menu of delicious food offerings makes it easy to waste a way an entire afternoon (and bank account - 1-liter beers run close to $20). 

Don't expect to catch the game here - no TV of any sort. In my eyes, a fifth star comes when you don't have to choose between the game and the Biergarten.
author: Marcus C.

description:
Pros: 
1) It's modeled after a traditional outdoor biergarten with communal tables, some shade, and a friendly vibe.
2) They have HUGE beers.
3) There are lots of traditional German snacks and entrees. 
4) It's close to BART and Muni.
5) They have clean bathrooms.

Cons:
1) This place is expensive! A 1/2 litre will set you back $9, a full litre is almost double that!
2) There are no ciders on tap, only in bottles.
3) Parking is terrible if you are driving.
4) Lines can get long.

Overall, it's a good experience, but you are going to pay dearly for it, so if you are just looking for cheap beers, there are better options around.
author: Brian S.

description:
Stopped here during a bachelorette bar crawl and have to say - way better than any smelly, stuffy bar you could otherwise go to. If you're trying to shirk the skeevy types, a well-lit picnic table ensures that only the most brazen will try to strike up a conversation - perfect for the jean-clad lady that just wants to have a goddamn beer in peace. 

The beer is alright, heavy on the hoppy options if that's your scene. They serve food, which is a huge plus, and I prefer the environment considerably to Zeitgeist. If it gets chilly (or never gets not chilly, I should say) there are fleece blankets to wrap yourself in. Biergarten scored fairly low on the hipster-o-meter when we were there, but we may have just gotten lucky. 

Bring cash, bring friends, and enjoy some outside beers. :-)
author: Laura B.

description:
Great place to hang out on a sunny day/night in SF. 

In terms of their food - pork sliders are my favorite - the pretzel is also good. the deviled egg was a bit too salty/sour. the line to order gets long - if you just want extra food, they have a separate line for limited food menus (cash only) - i usually go to the smitten ice cream after for desert :)
author: Miri Kwon R.

description: Authentic Bavarian food in Biergarten filled with French people tonight. Which is to say: Perfect for me!
author: Victoria E.

description: Such a cool outdoor spot for when the weather is nice. Great beer, good food, but the line to order takes foreverrrrr. Waiting is the only downside, aside from that love this spot.
author: Kelli L.

description:
A friend of mine tipped me off about Biergarten - it's not too far from his house in SF. As a good German girl, I had to see for myself if this was a good drinking spot or not.

The good:
- Conveniently located right off the Freeway - even if you aren't a city dweller, you can find this spot pretty easy. Simply exit at Octavia from 101 and you'll see it pretty quickly.
- Parking is easily accessible, even on the weekends.
- It's always fun drinking beer out in the sunshine.
- Very good beer selection. Not too many choices, but the ones they have on-tap are pretty good.
- Fresh baked pretzels to go with your brew. Yummy!

The not-so-great:
- As with many outdoor patios, Biergarten gets pretty crowded on a relatively warm, sunny day in San Francisco. You definitely need to be aggressive when it comes to finding a seat.
- Their Radler was disappointing. Having spent 3 weeks in Germany as an exchange student, I'm quite familiar with different varieties of lemonade/beer combos. This one wasn't good - way too sweet. Stick to the other drinks on the menu.
- Once the sun goes down, it gets pretty chilly this time of year. Bundle up and bring a blanket! You won't regret it.

Overall, a very decent drinking experience in the city. Come with a group of friends and plan on drinking some Litres. Very fun!
author: Abby S.

description:
If I wake up on the weekend & notice the sky is sunny, one thought immediately races through my head. "Today will be a GREAAAT DAY for BIERGARTEN!"

Yes, it's literally a parking lot with some benches & lights being hung overhead, with beer & german food being served out of shipping containers, but it's so AWESOME. 

On a sunny day in Hayes, it's hard to beat chilling and drinking beer with your friends and other locals in a communal outdoor setting. The one liter steins, brimming with beer certainly encourage feelings of joy as you bs the rest of your afternoon away with friends till your hungry. I mean sure, you can be productive with your day but why would you?

Meat knot? What's that? I don't care. It tastes good & bring me another stein please.

If you can't get enough of Biergarten, you should check out their sister restaurant Suppenkuche which is also in the neighborhood. They have delicious food and DAS BOOT, two whole liters of beer ready to help you stay tipsy. Watch the movie "Beerfest" for inspiration.
author: Steven C.

description:
This place is great!

The wooden park benches remind me of the bar on campus in Berkeley.
The string lighting eases an afternoon rendezvous into a romantic evening.
The open space and view of the Octavia Street Park provide a welcome respite from the towers of downtown.
The beer is served by the liter. Halfsies available too.

I like coming here to drink & draw.
author: Paolo V.

description:
Great place to hang out with friends and other friendly people. 
Definitely love the ambiance here; no one trying to start arguments, everyone's here to chill.
Got the 1/2 liter of the light beer and it was great.
I'm definitely hanging out here again and next time I'm ordering food; definitely looking forward to it.
Props, Biergarten, props.
author: Nathalie Y.

description:
This is the perfect place to come on a hot San Francisco day. Yes, I know they are rare, but when they DO happen, we all know you need to take advantage.

Some things are great because they're exactly how they sound -- this is one of them. I mean, who doesn't like to sit outside and drink massive glasses of beer with their friends?

Highly suggest getting the "light" beer if you're lucky enough to stop by here on a nice day. It's literally the most refreshing thing you'll have all day. The red ale is also a winner. Really, you can't go wrong with anything you choose, which is great because most things on the menu are written in German anyway. 

Biergarten has it all: great beer, cool food, nice outdoor space, fresh air, etc., so really I have nothing further to add. Just make sure to add this to your summer to-do list and come early -- Biergarten will be pretty packed on any day with prime weather, so you'll need to make moves in order to find seats at one of their long tables.
author: Brian S.

description:
An outdoor biergarten is like something straight out of a movie. Legally drinking in the outdoors in the middle of the city is such a great idea!! Why couldn't I think of this...

Anyway, I've only been here twice, and both times were great. I've tried the Frankziskaner $6 and Weiheinstephaner $6. Pretty standard pricing. I've also tried a few dishes - Pickled plate - I had no idea ginger can be pickled, same with carrots, garlic, and a few other things. Frankfurter - yummy sausage served with sauerkraut and a house dijon mustard. Pork Risette dish - which is served on pieces of toast and topped with mustard seeds and chopped chives. Everything was delicious and great for an afternoon snack/early dinner. 

If you ever have the chance to stop by Biergarten be sure to dressed in layers, the restaurant does have blankets out for the customers, but you never know with the bipolar SF weather. Cheers!
author: Elaine N.

description:
BEER: 4.5
Not a large selection of beer, but definitely a great one! I probably had one of the best hefeweizens I've ever tasted in the US; it was the closest thing to the hefeweizens I tried in Munich. The red ale was also a solid choice. 

FOOD: 3
Can't really say much, but I had their pretzels and pickles. Pretzels were okay, kind of dry. Homemade pickles were great.

ATMOSPHERE: 5
Outside, picnic style seating only. Laid-back. Cute. It reminded me of a backyard.
author: Annie N.

description:
A good time is always had at Beirgarten. The food is good, the beer is good, but the tables are always full on a good day and the line will be around the gate and out the door. I wish they could expand, but I understand that they are limited to their corner lot.

Despite the mass amount of people on a nice day/night, the beer is always good, always changing, and always worth the wait. Check it out!
author: Emily S.

description:
First time at Biergarten since living here! I've seen it, heard about it as a great place to go on warm nights, etc. When it was 80 degrees last Thursday, I decided to come. 

Lines were long, very long. My friend told me there  as a separate line for food, so I went up to the front to look around, and when I asked the RUDE employee (the one with the long beard) about the line, he snarkily said yes, that's the line, you would wait like anyone else. I'm sorry, who taught you how to treat customers WHO HAVE NEVER BEEN THERE? It's not unheard of to have two lines like you see at Shake Shack for dessert and all other foods in another line. What a d---.

Suffice to say that was a mood killer for such a great day. So I had the gnome burger and a cheese knot. The burger was good but small and $7, and the cheese knot was just okay for me. 

I liked the atmosphere and the lights at twilight. Would I come back? Maybe if I was forced to, but get some more polite staff... please!
author: Jeanne C.

description:
A few friends and I came to Biergarten after Suppenküche was packed to the brim. We were still feelin' the German beers, and the weather was perfect outside, so we staked our claim on one of the picnic tables. We got there around 9pm and it wad still pretty crowded, but we managed to find a free table pretty easily. 

The outdoor space is pretty cool, with a few shipping container type structures, serving beer and assorted German sausages, pretzels, and other bar food. We ordered our beers, and I ordered the pork belly sliders, which were delicious, including the red cabbage slaw it came with. I would recommend against getting the burger, because although it was delicious as well, it was about the size of one of my sliders and more expensive. The waitstaff is very friendly and they were very efficient with bringing out the food.

I love the raucous beer gardens where everyone is singing and having a good time, but after being a plane for 6 hours, I definitely appreciated how laid-back and chill Biergarten was. If you're looking for an Oktoberfest-type experience, Biergarten might not be the place you're looking for.

The only disappointing thing was how early it closes. 10pm seems a bit early, but I guess, as a sort of a pop-up beer garden, you have to be mindful of the surrounding neighborhood. Anyways, I'm a big fan, and I'll definitely be back for some good German fare and delicious beers.
author: Eric J.

description: Low and behold I heard they got their lease extended another 5 years. It was after a beer or two so hopefully this is not just another hazed SF rumor as I'd hate to see 58 lux-condo units here instead. Indeed it's always a pleasure to visit this peaceful haven in crazy Hayes Valley. Last time I was here I saw a lot of wimpy 1/2 liters begin drunk, so let me ask: why not do it real Munich style and opt for a full liter? Just be ready commit because that's a lot of beer (maybe try a sample first at the register.) I guess my only real complaint about the place is  there's no cover band blasting away tunes. Oh, and you can't really stand on the benches or on the table the way they do in Germany. But then again, there are probably less injuries here. I wish I could come here more; ping me if you want to catch a drink.
author: Brian J.

description:
There is just something exceedingly nice about being able to drink outside. Especially when it's out of really enormous mugs ::steins!:: filled with delicious refreshing German beer. There are some pils, some weiss beers, and a dark one to get you going. 

They also serve some food. We had the seeded pretzels which come studded with sunflower seeds with some mustard for dipping. The pretzels were tender and pretty great. We also had some brats with sauerkraut and I must say I was impressed by their quality. I've eaten a lot of brats in my day and these were pretty fantastic.

The line can be a pain but if you get there early it's not bad. Now go an enjoy the remaining days of SF indian summer we have.
author: Misha T.

description:
Oh. It has a name. I thought it was just some outdoor randomagical place where strangers cram in with each other onto picnic tables and drain crazy-sized glasses of beer amidst loudness.

We went on Halloween day, which upped the antics that much more. Plus, there was at least one birthday going on. My group had left while I stuck around to sing happy birthday over red velvet(?) cake. There was jack-o'-lantern carving too. But no one had candles, so I turned on the flashlight app on my phone and put it in their pumpkin.

People were super easygoing, including those waiting in the slow-moving bathroom line. Back at the tables, some dude was standing around in a tank top as chilly evening began to fall. I remember asking someone to lend the dude their cape-like thing, and it happened.

I think I got some random phone numbers and business cards too. Happy Halloween. Happy Birthday. Happy Biergarten.
author: Dan B.

description: Mmmm... Bier and pretzels! It doesn't get  any better than this! I had the fort point red which was on point! The gf got the organic Weiss which was extra good!!! This is a beautiful little spot, with lots of cool ppl to watch... Everyone is so up beat and happy! Feel like I'm in the pharell because I'm happy video!
author: Anthony C.

description:
Its awesome! But how could authentic German beer be bad, really? Ok, well, the one caveat-- there were babies here. Babies at a bar? Not the best idea.

BUT THEIR SAUSAGE! OMG. BEST BRATWURST I'VE HAD IN THE CITY! And I go for sausage quite a bit. 

Fun fact- don't come here on a tuesday. Despite the fact Yelp says they're open, they aren't, and you and your roommate will be pissed you're standing around outside a chain link fence and dirt area sans beer. True story.
author: Emily D.

description:
It seems like we've been waiting a long time for this place. Too bad the opening of this place has been set back time and time again because it's no longer summer. Rainy season is upon us and they will be closed. I love Suppenkuche to begin with so I knew there was no way this couldn't be good.

There's a cash only line for pretzels and pickles. The larger line is for everything, including beer and sausages. Though this line can take a long time, it's not that bad if you get yourself a liter to last yourself a while until the next one. I often find myself going to the bar many times throughout the night at a bar, but here, I can settle down with a large liter stein. The pretzel was pretty good, but not the best German pretzel I've had. It was a thin style with mustard and horseradish, comes in seeded or non-seeded versions. The bratwurst with saurkraut was delicious of course, bursting with clear meaty juice.

There are two restrooms that are very clean and roomy. Sinks are smartly located outside. The drinking area is composed of thin picnic tables and thin benches positioned in a radial fashion around a tree. The tables are really close to each other, so you can literally be trapped in the center with the tree if you exit the wrong way. Otherwise, I love the coziness of good company and warm yellow lights on a nippy evening. This really, is a biergarten.

The huge, glaring drawback is that the line to get into the place at all gets long. I understand that this must be nice once you're inside to not have people crowding around you for seats. But still. It's a funny situation. I felt like I was waiting at the border to go to the promise land and that bouncer was US customs. Either that or it felt like prison, but where being in prison was a good thing. Several other people from the inside were at the chain link fence consoling their friends on the outside. I know how this feels because I was on the outside.
author: Jennifer W.

description: Make sure to get here early if you're coming on Saturday or Sunday (and if you're going to a beer garden on a weekday, I want your life) as seating gets quite limited--and I suggest you get two beers your first time in line, because the line never seemed to die down on Saturday afternoon. The food selection isn't amazing, but it's a good complement to the beer, which is excellent.
author: Nick M.

description:
I apologize to the folks that run this place as it is really a 4 star business (at least) but the grumpy old man in me just has to knock one star for the lines and the crowds. Sorry. Hopefully, people reading this will be able to see that.

Every time I come here I hate it sooo much.....until I get my first liter beer in hand, then I calm down. Why? Crowded, you have to wait in a long line to order, then you have to kind of hover around the picnic tables and be little aggressive to get a spot for you and your friends. Oh, is that group leaving? No. What about that group? Yes. Oh wait, that one person in their group is just sitting there on her phone. She should get up. She's not getting up. Should I ask her if she's leaving? Are you leaving? 

This is ground central techie heaven so if that scene makes you a cringe a bit, make sure you get in line for beer right away. 

The beer and food are good, the atmosphere is great if you can get a spot.
author: max m.

description:
Overall impression: long lines and overpriced in general by a few dollars.

The food was good but the portion sizes were small (good enough to feed a child but not a grown adult). From the gate to the front of the line probably took a good 20 minutes and then another 15-20 minutes before we got our food. Good thing we had a beer while we waited.
author: Geraldine C.

description:
The good ol' beer garden. A novelty in SF (or maybe I'm just living under a rock) but plenty in all of Europe. SHIET this was good. 

Here you'll find some wonderful imported German beer offerings, from your nice and light hefeweizens to the dark lagers. Speak of the dark lagers, my all-time favorite go-t here o is the Köstrizer, a nice dark lager full of chocolate notes and a smooth finish. Think Guiness but more flavorful and not as heavy. 

Yes, the half-liters and liters are pricey, but you're essentially paying for this nice outdoor bar environment. Their snack options, especially the German pretzel, are outstanding. Pricey, but oh so delicious with that special brown mustard they serve. Didn't get to try the pickled deviled eggs, but friends liked it. 

Last, on a really cold San Francisco day (I mean really cold not the stupid usual 65 degrees), the Biergarten staff hand out blankets for all the patrons. Definitely makes you feel like a badass struggling through a Russian winter.
author: Thankie S.

description:
This is an outdoor rectangle of happiness. It doesn't get better than being outside, sitting at a picnic table with buddies, enjoying excellent German beers in big vessels and exposing your taste buds to an epic savory snack voyage. While it can get crowded, there is no other comparable rectangle of joy in San Francisco, and that's not the only thing that makes the Biergarten uber special. 

You really cannot go wrong with the food. As a sister to Suppenkuche, the Biergarten maintains the standard of shut the front door delectable flavor. Order literally anything, but I can speak for the bratbasket, pretzels, meat knot, potato salad, and the deviled eggs. Give your inner savoryphile something to rave about and order literally anything. 

Suppenkuche rocks my restaurant world, and the Biergarten is just another way to enjoy it's most excellent fruits. Prost!
author: Chelsea B.

description:
Classic SF (interpret this as you please). 

Yes, the vibe's kinda hipster with the fences and bar-shack-thingy. But as a non-hipster, I do love the vibe here. A small but solid selection of German beers, and the food's pretty good too (avoid the pickle jar; I can't stand pickled eggs and strawberries...). Perfect for catching up with a group of friends, so long as it's not a peak time and you can find an open table.
author: Alyssa Y.

description:
We came on a Sunday afternoon at around 1pm when they opened. Soon after, all the tables filled up and the lineup for beer and food reached 45 minutes. 

Food: curry wurst / bratwurst were delicious. Had the wheat beer too which was pretty good. Overall, pretty decent. 

Setting: picnic bench-type seating with no overhead shading. Bring sunblock or cover up. Lots of us got burned.  There are two separate washrooms for men and women though I was told there's a urinal in the women's washroom. 

Summary: prepare to wait. Bring sunblock. Go early for a table.
author: Andrew C.

description: Ok, the beer is amazing, only four stars for folks who call this place home. I was there on a Friday when they opened at 3pm.  Staff were amazing and efficient but I could not get over how exclusive the crowd was.  Considering that the only tables are communal tables, there was no sense of community.  I get it, you're out with your buddies from work or on a date but, the whole idea of a communal table is engaging with your neighbors.  If you can't do that, go somewhere else.  Not sure how the owners can change the behavior of customers but I was very disappointed.  I guess, invest in 2 tops with private heaters and everyone will be happy.
author: Leah Anne W.

description:
Celebrating a sunny and warm day at the Biergarten would be a normal thing to do.  My only experience at the Biergarten was when it was chilly and an hour before closing on a week night.  However, I really loved it!  They were completely out of food, which is a huge pet peeve of mine when going out, but we had no problem getting beer.  You can choose between a liter and a half liter.  Plus, If you come at night, there is a much shorter line, and there are wool blankets to keep you warm.

The selection isn't massive, but what they are serving is delicious.  I had the Schneider Weisse, and it was my favorite beer ever.  It had hints of banana and some spices, and I would totally recommend it.  It's a darker color, but it does not taste like it at all.  I tried sips of two other things as well that were good, but I have no idea what they were.  

What really warmed my heat over was that they have Almdudler.  I spent an entire summer in Austria and drank SO MUCH Almdudler.  While it's a bit more expensive than the home country, it was nice to see some non-alcoholic beverages with the German theme as well.
author: Amanda J.

description:
The two most probable reasons for having insanely long lines:

1) You are so popular that too many people want your stuff.
2) You are too dang slow at servicing your customers.

Thanks to a heavy dose of #2 and a smattering of #1, Biergarten delivers consistently on a promise of a long, long wait almost every time.

I get that they're popular. The location is pretty sweet and, even though it's basically set up in a chain link fenced parking lot, they've done a good job of making it feel cozy. 

I don't get how they're so, so, soooo slow. This is BEER folks, which comes out of taps and bottles. It's not craft cocktails that take meticulous care and attention to detail to create correctly, nor is it a perfectly slow-dripped individual cup of coffee. Beer - the same basic stuff that's whipped up in seconds at any other bar. Maybe they don't have enough people behind the counter? After 5 visits, I still haven't been able to figure it out.

Another thing to be aware of, and I state it here because, given their location and lack of signposting, it's totally non-obvious. Biergarten DOES NOT allow dogs. That's right: even though it's outdoors and in a parking lot, they won't let you bring your pup in. I'm sure they have their reasons for this but, as a dog owner looking for a cool place to chill during a nice summer day, it's a giant downer that makes me feel like "not fair!!!"

With all of that, I'd have given it a measly two stars. There's good stuff too, though, bringing it to a solid three. The food and beer are delicious, when its cold and windy (which is pretty frequent), they'll bring along cozy blankets to keep patrons warm. Its location right next to Smitten, Ritual, and a wide variety of other Hayes Valley spots makes it a tolerable destination for even non-drinkers. Be warned, though: the Biergarten staff does not look kindly on bringing outside food in to the place. I've literally seen people get kicked out for nibbling on a slice of Pizza.

So, all in all - a decent place to kill a sunny Saturday afternoon in Hayes Valley. Just leave the dog at home, and be prepared to invest a bunch of your day waiting in line. Whether you enjoy it despite the drawbacks is, as always, totally up to you!
author: Kevin B.

description:
The emplacement is just amazing. Right in the hearth of Hayes Valley, this is a huge outdoor terrace. Go enjoy the sun and great german beers. They come either in half or full liter, so brace yourself!

As it's outside, it might get cold on grey days or past 5-6pm. But no worry, they have a set of wool blankets you can borrow if you're getting cold!
author: Simon B.

description:
Line's suck - but can be worth it.

While it can be a veritable clustetr$%&(k on hot sunny weekend days, it is so for a reason. Beer is great, the food is better, the vibe is cool even when crowded - what else can one expect from the masterminds behind Suppenkuche? 

Five stars - even WITH The insane lines.
author: Oleg H.

description:
In order to avoid the ridiculously overpriced SF Oktoberfest, my friends and I headed to Biergarten to celebrate the first day of the world's greatest drinking holiday. Lines were out the door (or rather fence), but that didn't stop us.

Biergarten is a very simple concept. You get your beer, sit down at a table with your buds, and simply enjoy the blissful world of Hayes Valley around you. Aside from lights and umbrellas, there's no decorations. 

Beer selection is minimal, but high quality. For Oktoberfest, they had around 5 different beers, including the famous but mediocre Hofbräu Oktoberfestbier and the delightful Hacker-Pschorr Oktoberfest-Märzen. $7 for 1/2L and $14 for 1L. Pretty decent prices for high quality beer. 

In addition to beer, you get your choice of typical German street foods. Bratwurst, pretzels, deviled eggs, etc. It doesn't even compare with what you'd find at a festival in Germany, but it's good enough to balance out your beer. I got a Frankfurter, which is served with mustard and sauerkraut. Although it was pretty tasty, it's not worth $8. Most of the food items are heavily overpriced, so I advise you eat before coming here. 

The venue gets crowded very easily, especially on a weekend or such a big holiday, so scoping out seats is a must. They could easily put more tables in here. Also, since you're outside, be ready for the temperature changes. 

Overall, a great place to enjoy one of Germany's most vital contributions to American society.
author: Dmitriy S.

description: I love german beer gardens, but ultimately, this place isn't one.  It's a few picnic tables in a parking lot with some shacks to get drinks from nearby.  It's also always super overcrowded.  I like that they have german beers and that you can get them in a Maßkrug, but that's pretty much all they have going for them.  3 stars for the attempt...
author: Brendan B.

description:
So you know how there's those times when you're like, 'yeah, I could really go for a nice sunbathing session and a gallon of good beer?' (They happen to me more than I'd like to admit).

Well, Biergarten is your place.

While I can't promise you there will be sun, I can promise you you'll get your weeks worth of beer here. And it's awesome for groups with their picnic-style seating. 

Bonus points - it's right in Hayes Valley, which is also pretty-kick ass. So if you're feeling some pancakes before your gallon of beer, or you want ice cream after your gallon of beer, you're golden. 

Basically, if you like beer, go.
author: Amanda U.

description:
Like the name obviously suggests, Biergarten is a cool outdoor spot to drink some beers with friends.  Good German beer selection and they provide blankets for you if it's cold out which is obviously quite often in SF.  Some of the blankets, however, smell like a dive bar from all of the beer spilled on them, bringing a new meaning to the term "beer blanket," but at least they provide them if you failed to bring a jacket.

The only thing that needs to be worked out here is expediting the brew service.  It's ridiculously slow.  Even if you arrive when it opens you can still expect to wait 20 to 30 minutes in line to get a beer.  Want another beer?  Get back in line.
author: Erich D.

description:
Pretty good place to just hang out. Waiting in line is not so bad but lookig for a seat can be challenging especially when it's crowded

It's like winning a gold when you finally notice someone leaving and you quickly swoop on their seat! Whee!

Pilsner is pretty good. I only had the .5L and that was enough for me. My friend for the beef and cheese knot. Pretty good but didn't know it was going to be a sandwich. Lol.

Would come here again to hang out. Love being out in the city!
author: Carol Y.

description: Went on a Wednesday night at 7. It wasn't packed yet fairly full, there were a few tables open. Able to fit 8 where we sat. Had the Steiner Waisser (sp) pretty darn good!, and an awesomely warm pretzel with mustard and horseradish. They also have thick wooly blankets!, unfortunately they close at 9 :(. Great spot!, will be back.
author: Elizabeth T.

description: Great, charming place, but totally inefficient. You have to stand in line every time you want to order a beer or food! That's silly. This place would me so much more money if the staff was able to take order and deliver food. For that reason I give it one start. I want to leave after my first beer. Not standing in the line that goes around the corner.
author: Ian N.

description: Cool spot.  The lines however are kind of crazy, especially on a really nice day.  I just really like being outside.  I like the steins that they serve beer in and you can choose between two sizes.  This place gets really crowded and can be challenging to find a seat, especially for a large group.  I saw people order food, I did not, but it looked good.  Will come back again to try it.
author: Anh N.

description:
Can't beat the vibe when the weather is good, but you have to get hear early or the lines get long and the seats fill up.

Decent selection of brews that come in a giant masse.
author: Rob W.

description: The beer selection is sub par. And don't think about bringing outside food in here (even though that's not posted anywhere.) They'll yell at you and ask you to leave.
author: John R.

description:
This beer garden is awesome! It's basically a bunch of wooden picnic tables right in the middle of Hayes Valley, enclosed by a fence, so you can people-watch, or people can watch you drink your ginormous 1L beers. 

They have a great selection of German beers, and their pretzel (comes with mustard and horse radish) is so soft and delicious! This is a cool place to hang out with friends and grab a beer, or more like 3 (=1 liter). You could get less than 1 liter, but where's the fun in that? Smitten is also right next to this place so you can grab some ice cream after! 

But GET HERE EARLY, like before-it-opens-early because I guarantee you will wait forever in line. We waited 30 minutes before it opened and there were people in front of us who took all the shaded benches already, which was the reason for my sunburn this weekend.
author: Stephanie G.

description:
BIergarten was a spot picked out by a friend of mine for a group meet up.  A quirky collection of cargo shipping containers situated in a parking lot in Hayes Valley, I didn't know what to expect. 

Beer 6/10:  I don't must about German beer, but nothing here really blew me away.  Maybe it's just my tastes from the hop filled hills of California but the three German beers that i tried all seemed to taste the same.  The bartender at the end of the night was even able to give us a try of the Octoberfest beer they were going to have on tap the next day as they were switching out the kegs but even that just fell a bit short of expectations.  The bonus of course with German beer is that everything is served in liter glasses. By the time my brain had figured out the conversion rate of liters to pints it was already too late for me. 

Food 8/10:  For such a small location the Biergarten manages to put out a good variety of traditional German beer house food. Pretzel rolls and sausages smothered in spicy mustard and kraut area a must.  My favorite thing was the potato dumplings and bacon gravy, it warmed my heart and raised my blood pressure.  This is normally a special that they tend to run out of so if you get a chance try and snag a plate.

I'll definitely be returning to Bieragarten again just maybe when the weather isn't as cold.  It was great that they offered blankets considering it's an outside venue but i can see this place being huge in the warmer months.
author: Ryan F.

description:
Came here on a beautiful SF winter day.  Got a liter of beer with my bro (actual brother), and sat down next to some people. 

Ordered a pretzel with horseradish and mustard.  Eating horse radish feels like an inverted punch to the nose, coming from inside your head, and it really hit me good.  I love horseradish, and the stuff here was like the Falcon punch (super smash bros reference) of horseradish.  The mustard has the kick of a horse too.

They have blankets here for the cold.  Don't fear the long line, it's actually a good thing.  After you finish your first liter, your party can get up, go get some more liters, and find a new crowd to sit around.  It means you get to meet more people and get some different views on the beer garden.  This place is all about socializing.

While we were there, a wedding party decided to roll in and take pictures.  I'm not sure why you'd want to take pictures on your wedding day surrounded by random drunk people, but maybe you're into that kind of thing.  Everyone was clapping for them, but I had no idea who they were.  For all we know it could have been an elaborate street performance.

All in all, Biergarten is a good time.  It supplies you with a rich crowd and a social environment, and big beer to get you nice and saucy (OR BLOATED, but that's just me, right?).
author: Alex H.

description:
Great place to go and enjoy the patio. Like everything in the city expect a line but, if you have cash you can grab a pretzel or a pickle while you wait. Prepare to sit with strangers and have a giant beer. 

The food prices are reasonable and most everything was good. The knot was my fave but, the mustard was intense and dominated the taste of the braut and deviled eggs.

All and all worth the wait it takes.
author: Kristen R.

description:
Took friends visiting out of town to Biergarten for what i think is a very SF experience, arriving promptly at 3pm to find a line formed around the entire Biergarten's fence. Judging from the number of people and the side of the area i was afraid we weren't going to find a table. That worry quickly washed away when i realized we were actually standing in the food line and not purely an entry line. Once they open the doors anyone can walk right in and bypass the line to stake out a table! I highly suggesting splitting your party up - half find a table and half stay in line to order.

I truly believe i spend half my time waiting in lines in the city. Most of the time it's to eat at places like this biergarten where reservations aren't accepted. Almost 45 minutes later we finally place our order! Order all your drinks and food the first round because you will NOT want to get back in line.

The atmosphere is perfect for a laid back group who share a love of tasty beers and german food. It's trendy, in the middle of hayes valley, neighboring Smitten's ice cream and a Blue Bottle kiosk.The wind picks up like mad as the sun starts to dim. Drinking more beer doesn't always keep us warm enough! Luckily they know this at Biergarten and provide heavy duty blankets for us wimps in SF who can't handle a little cold.

Get the pickled deviled eggs, bratwurst with sauerkraut, and pretzels to go around. The horseradish only encouraged me to drink more beer!
author: Samantha L.

description: Love their beer! Love the atmosphere! Love their sausages! We need more of these authentic beer garden in the city! It is a great hang out place anytime of the day and kids friendly too.
author: Anita T.

description:
Relaxing outdoor space in the middle of SF? Yep, it does exist. Walking by you might mistake it for an rundown park with its miscellaneous picnics tables scattered about, but work taking the detour in. 

I visited on a Wednesday night when the burger special runs - a time I highly recommend. Less crowded than weekend afternoons and food is excellent. If it gets cold just ask for a blanket! They have plenty to share.
author: Chris H.

description:
What a GREAT place to chill, have a beer and soak in the rare SF sunshine! I've driven by here so many times and never realized that it was a biergarten because I think the conexes kinda threw me off for something more industrial or something. My friends and I parked our butts here right when they opened at 3pm on a Wednesday and we were enjoying our Spring Break from our intense nursing school program...so we had an excuse to drink in the middle of the day in the middle of the week. For the rest of the folks there, we just had to wonder what folks did for work who drank full liter steins of beer at 3pm.

Anyway, the beer is what you'd expect to find at any fine German establishment. They rotate beers by season and pour in 0.5 liter ($10) or 1.0 liter ($20) glasses/steins. It's too bad they don't sell beer by DAS BOOT! I guess those might break too easily... The only thing that could make this place even more awesome is if the women who work here wore those German biergarten uniforms. But I digress. 

The food here looks amazing, but I opted to just go for the beer and pretzels and had bites of my friends' burgers...which was pretty darn good. Next time I'm definitely going to try the pork belly sliders.

Overall, if you've got a big group of folks and want to just chill and hang out during a warm SF afternoon/evening, then come on over to Hayes Valley and sit your butts down here and enjoy a fat brew!
author: Sam L.

description:
This place is really cool! It is an outdoor place with community style seating on a big lot.  You go up to a shack like thing to order, and the workers are all really nice and cool. 

They have an array of beers, i think like 5 on tap and they werent all lagers and pilsners thankfully :) we also grabbed a bite, i got the mushroom sliders they were soo good. 

I would love to come back here on a nice sunny day for some day beers!
author: Kathleen D.

description: Great place to hang out on a nice sunny day with friends :) Unfortunately, was overcast the last time I went here, but luckily not too cold. I saw some blankets around, but I'm honestly not sure if they belonged to someone or if Biergarten just has them around for everyone to use. Great drinks and friendly staff. But boy does this place get busy! On especially nice days, it's not unusual to see a long line out front to get it. True to the "Hayes Valley" style with shipping containers, this is not a very large space. However, if you do manage to get a seat, it's worth it :)
author: Bianca C.

description:
Whether you're a local or just visiting SF, Biergarten is not to be missed! Ideal place for a "sunday funday" boozy lunch or just want feel like it's Octoberfest year round.

FOOD: Who doesn't love pretzels and beer?! If you are a weirdo who doesn't like beer, wine is also available for 6 bucks a cup (literally served in a cup). I recommend a liter of Munich Gold ($14) and a cheese knot (like a grilled cheese with shallots on an amazing fresh pretzel roll, $6) Lactose intolerant? Get the frankfurter on an equally amazing fresh pretzel bun with a sour kraut topper and spicy brown mustard-heaven! Anything you order will be delicious. Even if you are allergic to calories and order a kale salad-still awesome!! 

SETTING: Outdoor wooden benches situated in what looks like a parking lot with a chain link fence around it. Everything is served out of grey boxy bungalows and gives it a very industrial vibe. When the sun goes down and the temp drops, they have blankets available for those unprepared for SF weather. So thoughtful! 

TIPS: Bring money for the meter (they charge on Sundays now) and a deck of cards for fun drinking games if the conversation is lacking. Get there early! By 2pm, the line tends to extend past the gates and seating will be hard to come by as people like to camp out for the afternoon.
author: Talya C.

description: Had no idea this little place was here!  It was a super fun find.  Tried the pickled deviled eggs and couple of nice beers while hanging out in the sun.  Can't really ask for more.
author: Heather D.

description: Everyone in San Francisco needs to come here. Fun when it's nice weather outside. Quick note for first timers: the line is for ordering at the bar, and the place fills up pretty quickly, so send some people to get a table and the rest in line to order. You don't have to wait in line just to get in/sit! Unless the place hasn't opened/just opened of course.
author: Shawn T.

description:
Heaven on Earth.

btw- you want a "whiniest bitches in SF list"?  Read the reviews that give this place 1 star.  They all need to be checked.  

Long lines....whhhhhaaaaah!  
No dogs allowed........whhhhaaaaaah!   
Too busy......whhhhhhhaaaah!  

People in this city have no backbone.
author: Darin E.

description:
Why aren't there more places like this in SF?!

Finally checked Biergarten out yesterday because Suppenkuche had an hour and a half wait.  It was pretty freaking cold at Biergarten because it was 7 pm in November, but the staff was walking around handing thick blankets to everyone (: !!

Such a great place for day drinking or for celebrating a birthday with a large group.  Definitely coming back during the day.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Pros:
Great atmosphere 
Amazing beer
Superb staff 

Cons:
Quite pricey ($8sm/$16 lg)
Closes at 9pm

Overall, this is a pretty cool spot. I would definitely recommend giving it a shot of you want some good beer in a unique, laid-back setting.
author: Brent J.

description: Came here for a friends birthday on a sunny Saturday when everyone else in SF decided to do the same. It was SO crowded! The servers were aloof and overworked and too busy. We waited in a long, 30 minute line for a beer. Yes, I know waiting in line is what we "do" in San Francisco but is anyone over this yet? Just me? I don't get it. There are plenty of places to drink beer on a patio (and even get a bratwurst) in the city, not sure why this place is so special.  Brats were good though, I'll concede to that.
author: Kathryn P.

description: Found this place by chance while walking around San Francisco. This place is a great place to grab a beer and enjoy the outdoors. The atmosphere is one of a patio setting with just a relaxing vibe. All the beverages are German which I would have expected given the name. They had food there it looked good but we did not get any. Overall a great place to enjoy San Francisco's sunny weather when it is available. would definitely come back again
author: J G.

description: It's a interesting concept to have shipping containers in lieu of actually brick and mortar buildings.  It makes the area feel more hipster.  Regardless, the liter of beer tastes great no matter where or how it's served.  Please don't order half liters since you'll stand out as everyone else is chugging the large liter mugs with their dominant hand.  Since it's in SF, it can be rather cold in the winter so the patrons provide warm blankets for everyone.  Did I mention that it's outdoor and you sit on picnic style tables and benches?  While a great place to hang out, I still prefer an indoor setting.
author: Ronald L.

description: This place is awesome. On sunny weekends, expect to wait at least 30 min to get in. Service was very good. Lots of community seating. Lots of bike parking, good bathrooms, great beer list and reasonably priced for SF. Great crowd, food selection is German style pub food but good quality and fast service. The staff is very good. If you want to drink cold German beer in large steins and hang out (outside), this is the place you must visit in Hayes Valley.
author: Kevin D.

description:
The idea of having a beer garden in the middle of a beautiful neighborhood is awesome, but there's just so much waiting!

At Biergarten, you order your beer first, then look for a seat at the communal picnic tables... that is, if you can find one by the time you get your beer.  The line to get the beer is long, especially on a beautiful Sunday when the sun's out for once.  I only waited for about 40 minutes (keyword: about).  My friends have waited for as long as an hour.  Sorta ridiculous to wait an hour just to get a beer to sit outside.  

They provide blankets if it does get a little chilly!

But I do get why people's willing to wait.  Having a beer outdoors is just so much more enjoyable, especially if you can enjoy it from a legit litre glass.  Only German brews are carried here.  I do wish that they serve a bigger variety but I guess they are staying true!  You can get the smaller size, but just get the litre.  It's not worth it to go back in line just to get another and c'mon, you just look much cooler!

There was a polka band (I think) playing at the time.  Pretty cool!

In the end, cool spot, but the wait is too long for me, and I do wish there was more of a variety.
author: Duke C.

description:
Awesome! 
I love outdoor eating and drinking.
A "birretta" with a pretzel, enjoying San Francisco's winter sky? Awesome.
The staff is very nice, but the line might be long and clients might be a little too loud. But it's overall a pretty good experience! 
We definitely need more of these outdoor places in the city!
author: Amira T.

description: We recently visited SF and wanted to check out the Hayes Valley neighborhood. Our Uber driver dropped us off in front of this place and we were delighted! It was a sunny Sunday afternoon, the place was packed with happy patrons and the beer was delicious. We didn't order any food, but it looked good. Really cool, fun spot for beer lovers!
author: Meredith C.

description:
Didn't know about this place till my friend invited me down. I always pass this place off of 101 on to Octavia. It's kind of like, Munich meets steel shipping container land. The bathrooms, the vending areas, shipping containers. Luckily the seating/picnic tables (which BTW, after 4pm is nonexistent) are not.

It was a pretty nice day in San Francisco, OK it was 56F. Line already formed by 4...it took about 15 minutes to get to the front of the queue. They were out of the Bratwurst, but we ordered pork sliders, beef tongue, Asahi (BTW, it was Japanese themed today...is this a Japan/Germany/Axis thing?) and Edelweiss. All for about $40bucks.

Lucky for us, I found some milk crates to fashion a makeshift table and seats. Ate our dinner, froze our butts and a couple left a table, and we jumped on it.  Overall a very nice experience to chat, eat and drink a brew or five.
author: Reyz A.

description:
Biergarten is an awesome place to drink outside and relax with your friends. I want to give this place 5 stars but I had to take a star away because of the really long wait in line to order drinks. The line goes all the way outside of the area, so much that when we first got there, I thought it was a line to get in. 

The beer is good. You can get one of the large beers for about $16. There's also a bunch of different food here you can eat after drinking. I suggest having one or two people waiting in line. Once that person is close to the front, everyone needs to give their ID's to that person and they would just order all the beers. When we brought the beer back, we didn't give the ID's back to people until they gave us money for their beer lol. It worked out in the end since most people had cash. 

There's a bunch of seating but it's good to get here a little early to have someone save seats, it does fill up fast. But people are friendly and don't mind sharing the tables with other people. It was sunny when we came here but there was a slight wind, which made it great. My friend told me on really nice days, this place gets crazy packed. Later on in the early evening it started getting cloudy and chilly. But that's SF for you, so be prepared. 

The bathrooms are in the back. The guys restroom is just one room and inside there's the toilet seat and the urinal. The faucet is back outside in middle between the men and women doors. 

Overall, this is a great place to day drink, chill and enjoy the weather outside with friends. The wait to order beer/food is a bit long but not too bad if you wait with a friend.

Pros:
-1L beers for $16
-Outdoor sitting
-Great place to chill with friends

Cons:
-Line to order beer/food can take awhile
-No music
author: Paul U.

description: Unique place to have some beers in the heart of Hayes Valley. I was so interested in how this place operates especially through container cans. Never seen anything like it. It's basically one huge patio! Offering free blankets when the weather gets cold! Their beer selection was good and heavy! Must try! Good for big crowds!
author: Ladonna A.

description:
I like this spot for the (hopefully) sunny seating, huge liters of beer, and after those are both done, the proximity to drunkenly buy an $80 tee shirt in the shops nearby and feel like you deserve it. Size up because the German beers and pretzel knots are so good! 

The crowd can get a little Vampire Weekend-ish, if you know what I mean, but we always have a fun time eavesdropping on groups of a few dudes picking up on a few ladies. My boyfriend and I have learned some real slick ones, most of which have shockingly been successful. Maybe because they're all wearing sunglasses?

Someone else mentioned patrons are generally friendly here, and while that's mostly true, there have been a couple times after waiting in the very, very long line that some drunker than me fool tried to jump in front of us. Tensions were high, but the situation cooled when he just let us know he was cutting because he "wanted a beer" ....?

The family that runs it is rad too; always friendly.
author: B B.

description:
Amazing find tucked away in Hayes Valley. A low key beer garden with good food, beers, and atmosphere for post work shenanigans.

Though this place was crowded on a Friday afternoon, I was able to squeeze myself at the end of one of their tables, liter beer in hand. (Not as exciting as the 2 liter boot I attacked at Leopold's, but definitely reminiscent of pint/liter night in college). 

Their pork belly sliders were pretty memorable, though they are small. I really wanted a pretzel :( but unfortunately by the time I had reached the front of the line they were out. Next time!!
author: Michelle L.

description:
Ordered 4 beers, 2 were served very warm, nearly room temp.  LIne was too long to deal with complaining.  Food was decent and the only thing keeping this place as an option for me in the future.

I changed my review to 1 star because upon further investigation I figured out the problem here.

They store their beer in a metal container type thing that didn't appear to be refrigerated.  On a sunny day like the day I went, surely the temp inside this container has to be 80 degrees+.  If a keg needs to be swapped out during the day or just before opening, it would take hours for a warm keg to cool down in a serving fridge near the taps.  I'm sure I was just victim to a newish keg that had not had the chance to cool down.

How do other bars solve this issue?  They store kegs in fridges... for a place trying to be a legit beer destination, HUGE FAIL on their part.
author: Shawn A.

description: What a cool concept! I love the fact that you can hang out here and enjoy the sunshine and nice weather during the day and into the evening. The fact that they also serve German food is a nice touch. My only qualm is that I wish they would stay open later and bring out heat lamps, as this could make for a really great date spot or place for late night shenanigans. Also, their beer selection is a liiiiittle slim. Overall, great idea - SF needs more of these!
author: Molly V.

description:
We first noticed the line and crowded picnic tables filled with twenty something's drinking beer out of small, medium and large steins.

This fun and lively outdoor restaurant in the Hayes area of SF had a good selection of draft German beers and also had great food. The bratwurst and potatoes with horseradish and mustard was really great. Their pretzels with mustard were also delicious.

Give this place a try and dress warmly or find a sunny day. The area shopping on Hayes street nearby is also worth the trip there.
author: Jeff S.

description:
The idea is awesome.  Fence off an outdoor area and serve beer.  On a sunny day, it doesn't get any better than this if you you are just looking for something to pass the time by with some good friends.  

The Beer:  The beer is good German imports.  It's not gonna blow your mind away or anything, but its good.  They usually have 2 or 3 on tap.  And you have two size options.  The liter or half.  $14/$7.  

The Food: Didn't try, but the pretzels looked good.

The Setting: In the middle of Hayes Valley next to a park and some other food stands makes it a gem in the city.  There is plenty of sun when the sun is out and a lot of SF culture.  Not much to the fenced off area but the food bar, beer bar, and picnic tables to hang out at.  Simple. 

What I don't like:  The lines.  I recommend getting a liter if you planning on hanging around for a bit.  As with most things in SF, lines here can get ridiculous.  Of course this also depends on how lucky you are.  Anything after lunch is insane on a sunny day.  It could take you almost half an hour to get a beer and seated.  And you'll have to get back in line if you want more beer!  Maybe an express line for those that already got beer and just want a refill? If that was the case I would have given this place 5 stars!!!
author: Veasna H.

description: Great place to drink beer with your friends, when the sun is out. Try to avoid this place when it's super busy. I waited a long time in line (45 mins) to get in and the beer is a little pricey ($9/half liter). At least the food came out quickly.
author: Michael B.

description:
When it's sunny in SF, I highly recommend checking this spot out! It has an ample amount of outdoor seating (picnic tables). It's a pretty social place, which makes it awkward for those weird SF techies (not me)! I recommend coming here with a group of friends but would not recommend coming here on a date. 

Now... let's talk about the important stuff... the beer! I was impressed at the size of the beer that they serve. You can either get a very large beer in a glass or a HUGE glass. Honestly, unless you're chugging the huge glass, why would you get it? Beer is pretty nasty once it's warm, so go with the smaller glass, which is still very big! 

This place is located in a great location. There's tons of parking, it's close to muni/bart/freeway and if it's sunny in SF, it'll be sunny here! 

Service is ehh... whatever. You order up front and then you go sit down. The woman that was working there when I was here a couple of weekends ago wasn't friendly and didn't seem like she wanted to be there - maybe she was having a bad day?
author: Anastasia N.

description:
This is easily my favorite outdoor place to drink with friends. I came here with a group that started out as 3 and grew to be 8, taking over a whole table. Finding seating was far easier than I anticipated for a beautiful Wednesday night around 6pm. The beer line also went much quicker than you'd think for how long it was. Our group loved the red ale, the gnomeburgers and the various types of knots (I'd say the best was the guest knot). Can't go wrong with crispy prosciutto (two words that clearly belong together). I also love that they provide blankets for those who somehow forgot what the weather in SF is really like. 

I'll be back soon!
author: Eliza D.

description:
BURGER WEDNESDAY.

Every Wednesday they serve a different burger - check their Instagram for delicious details each week. One of the best burgers in SF. Also Wednesday's are waay better then coming on crowded weekends.
Side note: my bf and I tried 4505's burger one day - We were super unimpressed and left with a burger craving hugely unsatisfied. Immediately headed to Biergarten to fix that.

Actually everything on their food menu is awesome. Try the pretzel knot with crispy prosciutto! 
Oh yeah the beers are amazing too :)
author: Carla E.

description:
Fun place to come for happy hour on a sunny day. There are long lines for food, drinks and the bathroom but its just because its busy.... 

Grab a stein and a picnic table and enjoy.
author: Leah B.

description:
The hours here are the worst. That's the only drawback I've found -- except for the bizarre drunk idiots that accosted us several times. But I just kind of have that vibe I guess.

The beer was great, the pretzels with their home ground mustard and pickles were savory and different, the white wine was bearable. We sat out in the biergarten in the california sunshine *and then rain* and enjoyed a cold mug of beer and some super friendly service from the folks behind the bar. It's a bit on the pricey side -- but then isnt everything in CA? 

If you're in the area, and the line isnt wrapped around the block, sit down, have a beer, look at the world passing you by.
author: Kelly S.

description:
Biergarten has that classic outdoor patio vibe that's great for hanging out with your favorite homies over a few pints that makes you feel like a viking (the pints make my arms feel tiny and weak). As a derivative of Suppenkuche, it's an extension of the German joint in terms of space, only featuring a much more limited menu. With only a couple lagers to choose from and a small selection of bar snacks (think: pretzels, sausages, pickle jars), Biergarten serves you mostly for a cool outdoor atmosphere when you want to impress your friends from out of town who aren't ready for the grit and grime of a typical SF dive bar. If you want more to taste, I would suggest just going to Suppenkuche down the street instead for a full meal and a better selection of beers. If you're looking to just chill on a rare sunny SF day, this is the place.

Things to know:
- On really nice weekends, get there when it opens (3pm) to snag a table before it gets too crowded
- They don't have space-heaters, so get cozy with some blankets provided in the far corner
- They have 2 stalls of clean restrooms, so drink to your heart's content!
author: Marina L.

description: This place is so fantastic, I wish there were more like it. When the sun is shining and the people are smiling, this is the place to come to for yummy snacks and large portions of beer. Literally the only downside to the place is the line it can get on the weekends, but that only speaks to how appealing it is to the citizens of San Francisco. There are lots of different kinds of people here, ranging from dirty hippies to fresh hipsters, and I love them all. It's hard to justify revisiting a place as much as I do this one, but I don't care and I never will. Brunch, shopping, park, fancy candy and ice cream nearby are the multiple cherries on top of this cake,
author: Sarah B.

description:
Tell me why.

One reason why Germany's Paul Van Dyk is awesome: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2mCQEM3FugM

Few reasons why German Biergarten is awesome: Excellent homemade veggie sliders, delicious beet salad and a full of flavor (and sauerkraut) bratwurst on a pretzel roll.

Plus homemade pickles and a Weihenstephaner lager so light and easy to drink that there was a bit of regret on this warm(ish) July night for not getting the large size.

Much like a packed PVD show get ready to be close with your neighbors as seating is all at communal tables. Atmosphere is lively but not too loud.

At roughly $25 a person this will not be a cheap excursion. But like a really good DJ experience a really good dining experience shouldn't be either.

Enjoy finding your own reasons for giving four stars.
author: Jason B.

description:
If there were a dictionary entry for Biergarten, it might looks something like this:

bier-gar-den [beer-gahr-dn]  
noun
1. a fertile and delightful spot or region ripe for consuming beer in the great outdoors on beautiful days in san francisco.

2. zeitgeist's older, more successful/affluent, less-tattooed, and better dressed sibling in hayes valley.

True story.

Unlike Zeitgeist, however... it'll take you at least 30 minutes of standing in a single-file line to get a beer on a nice day. Heed the advice of the folks pouring and order all (yes... even if you're planning on staying for multiple hours) of your beer at one time. Even if it gets a little warm, it's much better than standing at the back of the line once you reach the bottom of your glass. Trust Uncle Ruggeford on this one, kiddos.

For the non-beer drinkers, they have a house red and house white option as well. In vino veritas!
author: Ruggy J.

description:
Three star is for service because they not allowed you to bring outside food and you can not have to go beer and the stuff is not friendly 
The beer they have is the best you can find around
author: Iulian V.

description: Great environment for beers and brats. The Bratdog is in a pretzel bun. Sauerkraut is fresh. Tasty. The Andrechser Doppelbock was dark and strong. Fun.
author: Alan K.

description:
As a resident of Hayes Valley, the Biergarten is at the top of my "Go To" List. It is a perfect place to enjoy the afternoon sun with a cold beer and some great bar snacks, like the soft pretzel's, pickles and brats.

The staff is friendly and the location is centrally located right on Octavia in Hayes and is a few steps away form the shopping and other attractions in the area.

The Biergarten is a popular spot, so the line can get pretty long. My advice is order all your beers at once... and if you are contemplating a half v full pint, always go with the big boy. You will thank me when you don't have to get back out of your seat and wait 20 mins in line for a beer.

Overall, I like the experience and day drinking is a SF specialty, so this is a great spot to make it happen.
author: Justin O.

description: For a perfect spring day & summer night....love the outdoor feel and the monster drinks they have on hand. The waiting in line and hovering over the tables staring down peeps so you can sit is a bit disturbing but once you do find a table...sit there..enjoy your wealth of drinks and good eats!
author: Kim H.

description:
FOOD:
I'm not totally into what is this... German food? Kinda immediately unhealthy & unsatisfying munchings. I would only go here if I wanted an outdoor spot to drink beer at.

ATMOSHERE:
Outdoor area, bunch of picnic tables to munch on stuff and drink BEER. Went to a Google event here, so even better bc the tab was taken care of. Yee. Middle of Hayes Valley so there still bunch of places around to go before or after or stroll around window shopping. 

8.13
author: Angela L.

description:
Hipsterville. 
Beards and Bikes. 

HUGEGANTIC delicious beers and the food options are very complementary. 
It's a little crowded, but a nice little sunny outdoor spot to hang with friends.
author: Anazette D T C.

description:
I like this place.  It's chill, fun & reminds me of the biergartens in Germany.  *heart*
*review on food & service

Beer:  dunno....  didn't try any.  But the steins are stellar.  

Food: Pretty tasty/fancy for a biergarten.  Was kinda hoping for schnitzel.  ; )  
I got pulled pork sliders & root salad.  All very tasty.  - B+

Atmosphere: Picnic tables in an enclosed area.  Good for small to medium sized groups.  We had 10?  
Great place to hang out outside w/ friends, drink & be merry.   Card games are fun!  Some Cards against humanity anyone??  

Service: Slow.  Not sure why, but takes awhile for them to pour your beer... i.e. the lines moves very slowly.  

Verdict: Great for a warm, sunny day.  Get there early b/c it fills up quickly!
author: CatwomanRoar M.

description: Excellent beer, bratwurst , deviled eggs and pork belly sliders. Will try the other things on their menu soon!
author: Vaibhav S.

description:
This place has GREAT potential, thus 4 stars... I know we went when it was their fourth day open so they've got some kinks to work out. RIDICULOUS lines for entry, beer, and food aside, my only real complaint?  THE BOUNCER...please enjoy my rant.

Saturday 10/22 in SF was absolutely gorgeous, it was in the 80's around 3:30pm when we got in line to get into the Biergarten.  The line wrapped around the block and took us 20-30min before we got to the front for entry.  When only one group was left in front of us, we noticed some random guy just walk up to the front of the line (came from the non-line side of the block,) and start searching his pockets for his wallet.  My bf notices this and actually calls this DB out, "hey man, are you with someone or are you cutting the line??" bewildered man's response, "oh um, i have friends inside..." disgruntled bf: "dude i've got friends inside too and i still waited in this line to get in."  so the guy actually acknowledged this and went to the back of the line...score one.

so now we're at the front of the line, and it happens yet again...some b*tch just walks up and shows the bouncer her ID and the bf calls out this woman too... "hey i just chewed some a**hole out for cutting in front of everyone...you need to wait in like the rest of us."  skank "oh i have friends inside," "WE ALL have friends inside dude!" and the girl must've felt entitled and was like "uh huh" & whipped her hair at this and proceeded inside.
