At this point we turn to the bouncer and ask if he's gonna keep letting people in and his lame response was "we just opened a few days ago, we're still figuring stuff out..." really??  i wanted to make the funny/dramatic point that society will start falling apart at the seams if he can't obey the rules of a line.  i mean really dude, DO YOUR JOB.  you're gonna have riots (not really,) and disgruntled patrons...this isn't cool.

upon entry into the biergarten, we weren't 5ft in the door when it happened a third time and this time I was fired up and called them out...and yet again the response they felt justified cutting the line because "we have friends inside." man i guess i should've just done that upon arriving too... i had friends inside too but i still waited! grrr...

ok enough ranting already... after all that hooplah, we still had a wonderful time.  beer line was awful so i can't wait for them to figure that one out.  i still would totally come back, i love the feel of this place.  yay beer n pretzels!  (oh and they said at some point they will be getting a pretzel warmer, yahoo!)  the pretzel came with mustard and horseradish which i'd never had but was TOTALLY delicious!!  and the bacon saurkraut?  FANTASTIC.   mmm.... go here, you won't be disappointed.
author: Sara W.

description: I love Biergarten, but the lines are too long, it's hard to get seating, and the food and drink are overpriced. Other than that, thumbs up.
author: R J.

description:
The sausage and curry potatoes are delicious! Beers are sort of expensive but I like that it is a patio and there is very cool people in this joint. When the weather is  nice it is a really cool spot to hang out and meet new people. I like the fact that they give you blankets at night if it gets cold. 

Only tried one of the beers, looking forward to visit again and try a different one.
author: Elizabeth D.

description:
We were exploring Hayes Valley and stumbled onto this fenced off section known as the Biergarten. There were plenty of benches all in which many different parties were sharing. You place your order at a counter that is made out of a large storage shed. I thought that this gave the establishment a unique characteristic. The menu is listed alongside the shed with a list of at least 10 biers as well as small tapa dishes like pretzels, pickles, and sausages in a mini plastic basket.  
 
They offer you number placards for your order and deliver food to your table. Its a gorgeous place to relax on a sunny day. Of course, when ever I can, I order the .5 Liter of Radler (lemon flavored beer).  
 
The enclosed area is very neat and tidy. Definitely another neighborhood gem.
author: Becky Q.

description:
Afternoon snack/meal brought the three of us here. We ordered the trio of salad, meat sandwich, beef tongue sliders, two pop and a beer. 

The salad consisted of kraut, roasted beets, and potato salads. I'm usually not a fan of potato salad, but this one was delicious! The beet salad was awesome as well and you can't do wrong with kraut. The sandwich was salami and kraut in between a halved soft pretzel. This was great as well. The pretzel was amazingly soft. We wanted to order just a pretzel, but we were full. I didn't try the sliders, but I heard they were scrumptious too!

Overall a great outdoor eatery in Hayes Valley. I loved the environment and atmosphere
author: Leslie P.

description:
We came here yesterday (Thursday) for happy hour knowing that it had just opened last week and were expecting a crazy line. We strolled up around 6pm and there was no line to get in! Prime HH time and no line? :)

The line for beer was kinda long, but moved quickly. We ordered our steins of authentic hofbrau beer and found a picnic table for six. The crowd was really chill and respectful- no drunken, beer splashing younguns like I had expected. 

Food wise, I only had a pretzel. Overpriced and skipable. I do want to try a bratwurst next time though.

The staff were awesome.. cheerful and always making sure to shoot you a smile if you walked by them.

My brit husband who lived in Germany for a year gives Biergarten his beer loving stamp of approval- that makes it 5 stars alone right there.
author: Seema M.

description:
i love, love, love, love biergarten. it's everything i love - good beer, outdoor seating and german bar food. deviled eggs, sauerkraut, pretzels, sausages...everything you could ever want in an establishment, right?

i would come here so much more often if it wasn't as pricey as it is and if i didn't have to be so aggressive to just find a place to sit. that being said, i still love this place and even had a birthday here.
author: Mandy A.

description:
I really liked this spot...it's perfect for Hayes Valley.

On a nice, sunny day, this is the perfect spot for enjoying beer, wine and a small selection of edibles outdoors.  The beer options are great and after sampling a few of them, I really enjoyed everything.  The food was very good too - I had a wurst with sauerkraut, both of which were fresh and fantastic.  The pretzel was fresh and perfect as well.

This place is extremely popular and people will be put off by the long line to get in.  Seating is limited so you just have to expect it.  

The crowd is very cool and chic, but still laid back.  

I can imagine it being an irritating place to be on a cold, overcast or windy day (most days during a summer in San Francisco?), so I'd suggest making sure the temperature is going to be sunny and perfect before going.
author: Ken G.

description:
Okay beer but count me in on a sunny SF day! 
I had huge expectations, Biergarten, because you're German. 
Your Organic Wheat beer was a disappointment but I liked the easygoing environment. 

Please surprise me with your dark beer next time! I'll be back!
author: Jiwon M.

description:
How is it possible that this place is packed, full, and the line for beer is almost around the corner at 3:30pm on a Sunday! Also considering they open at 3pm! Waited an hour for a beer, and it's not because the staff was moving slowly.  It appeared that people who were sitting down with their drinks, kept "cutting" and asking their friends who were waiting to get them more beers.  It feels like all the yuppies and hipster wannabe's trek it to hayes valley for the biergarten. Makes the place a little pretentious, and ignoring all of it, it's a great spot.

The beers are delicious and refreshing. Their bratwurst basket is amazing and out of this world. Sauerkraut was done perfectly. Love the pretzel, so soft and buttery.
author: Vanessa K.

description:
Great spot for an afternoon beer! Several good German selections on tap, some decent-looking food options (only had the pretzel, but there were other offerings), and a surprisingly nice ambiance for being made up of converted shipping containers and basic benches on asphalt. Friday crowd filled up pretty quickly after the 3pm opening, and the beer line never really got short- recommend an early arrival and ordering the 1L beers to minimize trips.

Hopefully other SF entrepreneurs will take note and create more spots like this- very convivial and fun.
author: Thomas R.

description:
Food was amazing, beer is cold and refreshing. Friendly and fast service. Great place to spend an afternoon with friends. 
The cider is crisp and refreshing without being too sweet.
The sausage platter is fantastic.  The pretzel is served with horseradish and mustard, and the pickles are fresh and crisp.
author: Kristin D.

description:
It's closed on Tuesdays, which is one of my days off, so it sucks that I can't come here on that day. 

I've only had beer here, it's a place where we either stop by before or after dinner. 

It's outside, right across from a play area so if you have kids, you can definitely dump them there and pop into Biergarten for a drink (I actually suggested this to a friend and he said it was a good idea, but he never did it.)

When it gets cold you can use one of the blankets that they offer but it's itchy and who knows who's been using it, so I really suggest you bring your own to use if you are anticipating the weather to be cold.
author: Serinda O.

description:
Been here twice in the past two weeks. Solid beer and food options, though slightly expensive. The bratwurst was amazing! 

There's nothing special about the place though, nothing that gives it any character, that's my main complaint. But overall it's a nice place to grab a beer outside on a nice day.
author: Rowena L.

description:
I really like this place, although it's a little pricey. 

I can forgive them for the beer because it's imported and it's delicious, but the food is pretty steep for what you get, even though everything I've tried here has been been delicious. It's fine if you're just trying to have some snacks with your beer, but don't try to eat here for dinner when you're hungry like I did. My boyfriend and I met up here for dinner, split two things, and had to have a second dinner a couple hours later. Maybe we should've had more beer. I can appreciate that they seem to change up their menu, one time they had delicious mushroom sliders and the last time I was here they had a variety of tacos.


The ambiance is great. I've only been at night but it seems like it'd be a great spot to hang out during the day.
author: Sarah W.

description:
Finally been to the Biergarten - it's across the street from me but it took me 10 months to try it! Good thing for half days. And a testament to how popular it is!

Beer selection is okay -- you could always go to suppenkuche for beer without a wait. The real advantage is having a pretzel, a pickle, or a brat outside on long picnic tables with groups of up to ten to a table.

They carded a friend of ours who was over 40. He didn't have his ID because we were doing a company offsite before that required running. They didn't care. Color me ignorant, but that feels like some pretty unempowered employees IMHO. Are we in sf?

Die Bier garten habt real estate but that's it in my opinion. Outside drinking and food and ample space? Go to the falafel place.
author: Christophe C.

description:
We came on a Thursday night around 6, which turned out to be perfect. We managed to nab two picnic tables for our group and there were just enough people for it to feel cozy but not quite crowded. The line varied from about 5 to 10 deep for beer & food, which was fine. So I'd recommend it for a  Thursday - I walked by on a nice Saturday afternoon and there looked to be about 10x as many people.
Honestly, I wasn't wild about the beer - I guess I'm generally preferring ales to lagers now, but the food is pretty good. The brats were a bit too mild but the pretzels were great and the pickled & deviled eggs were fun to try.
author: Lisa K.

description:
There is nothing to not love about Biergarten.  Well, ok.  There is one thing.  Two things, actually.  One:  They could use more taps, especially on days when the weather is great.  Two:  the fact that their lease will be up soon. That will be a sad day when Biergarten closes it's gates for goon. 

Apart from that, Biergarten is perfect.  The beer is awesome and German, with a choice of sizes.  The snacks hit the spot, perfect drinking snacks like the pretzel, my favorite.  Let the Steigl flow forever, Biergarten.  I love this garden!
author: Roland C.

description:
"German beer in a glass stein on a sunny Saturday afternoon in San Francisco" is an oddly specific answer to give when someone asks what my favorite color is.

Oddly specific, long-winded, and tedious, but honest.

Your first priority should not be getting a table, going to the bathroom, or waiting for friends - it should be getting in line for your beer. My friend and I made the novice mistake of commandeering seats and taking lavatory breaks and suffered the consequences: forty minutes in line waiting to order our drinks. The sun beat down on the back of my neck and ears, freckling my face in a very un-German way as I gazed enviously at the wise folks already sipping their authentic Bavarian brews from steins so full and so heavy they had to be lifted with two hands.

Despite the wait, this place is glorious. Beer (German-brewed tongue-twisters in name and in flavor) comes in liters or half-liters, both of which stay surprisingly, blissfully cold no matter how long it takes you to polish them off. Traditional German fare includes pretzels with horseradish and sharp mustard, sliders, and bright, pickled seasonal things (eggs, grapes, carrots, and cabbage are common menu tenants). You'll probably end up sharing a table community-style with some pretty chill people; you'll probably really wished you'd paid attention in high school German; you'll probably want to go back again next weekend.
author: Lauren H.

description:
The place is basically five shipping containers and a fenced in lot.  The beer was good but VERY pricey.  The food was good but VERY pricey.

ALL seating is outside.  ALL picnic tables to be shared with whoever wants/needs a table.  No roofs over any tables.

Reminds me of the story of "The Emperor Has No Clothes".

If the food and drink was cheaper, I'd give them a better review.  I spent $70 on two 1 liter beers, one cider and one order of sausage and potatoes and tip.  To me, that's pricey.

The place looks and feels like a prison yard with the chain link fence.

Don't get caught up in the hype.  There are places that MUST be just as good with better ambiance, food and beer for cheaper.  Skip it!
author: William F.

description:
Came on a Sunday afternoon, had no problem getting a table. We actually switched because the guys we were sharing the first one with were geeking out over some HTML writing and the "hella" was slowly driving me to implosion. We quickly found someplace else to sit and then shortly after that, the older woman working sat an obviously lost couple at the end of the table. I thought it was kinda cool that they help you sit if you're a shy newbie.

The beers are nothing to write home about. They don't have many... about 13-15 available, but I enjoyed my light beer, my husband enjoyed his dark beer and my friends chugged their gigantic ones. We're from LA, where people don't do communal, so it was nice just to sit and BE with other people--- I noticed a distinct diversity in ages, races, orientations, families, etc. Also, people actually spoke to each other... rather than getting lost in their cell phones. Wonderful to see.

Fun way to spend a couple of hours and great for those new to SF. If I lived here, I'd definitely come back and bring out-of-towners.
author: Donna J.

description:
Dam fine place for afternoon buckets of hardy German beer and devilishly tasty snacks. Speaking of snacks, don't miss their blood devil eggs and most any dessert they have on the menu.

Best: location, beer garden, people watching, next to park and food
Not so Best: parking, long line, no cocktails, need lots of sunscreen
author: Jai D.

description:
Fun outdoor beer garden with tasty beer and yummy sausages.

Even on a rainy, dreary day, expect this place to be filled to the brim and quite busy. The selection of beer is not extensive but enough to accommodate different palates. Our favorite was the currywurst which was a sausage with a delicious spicy tomato sauce, perfect in the cold.

Will definitely come here again, although it'd be nice if their beer was a little more reasonably priced.
author: Amy D.

description:
Pro: Great beer. Beautiful, refreshing location even when its windy as fuck and you're freezing your buns off (they have blankets). 

Con: Food is yum but TINY for what you pay...Expected for Hayes Valley so, in regards to location, sensible. Also, you kind of feel like you're in an episode of Portlandia. HIPSTER CENTRAL. Mustaches galore. 

Synopsis: Go with a group of friends. The tables are huge and make sitting together, easy. Also, you order on your own so no awkward, "should we split the bill" convo.
author: Amy C.

description:
Just get your  stein of good beer and enjoy! Awesome place to have couple good beers with good friends. The place always looked packed - but somehow we always managed to find a spot for a group of 4-6 ppl. You will be sharing long tables, that's expected. All seating is outside - and they provide blankets if beer does not keep you warm enough. 
 One wish - expand collection of pilsners and get more food choices.
author: Sergey R.

description:
This is touch because this is a pretty unique establishment and i dig the concept but the line is unreal sometimes! Good beer though and the $4 pretzel I tried was pretty good. Delicious when warm but it got so cold that my pretzel didn't take too long to get cold too :(

+1 for bringing out blankets to everyone when it got colder. That was nice :)

Unfortunately weather is a huge factor in how enjoyable this place will be for me...Unless you have an alcohol blanket on, which can be difficult with the long lines!
author: An-Nhien L.

description: Really chill place to drink at 3pm on a Sunday in the open. The snacks/appetizers are really good too! The only downside is if you come late, expect a long line and maybe no bench seating.
author: Vid D.

description:
First of all, I have to say the whole concept of a "beer garden" is freaking awesome! Biergarten is exactly what its name implies, which is essentially an casual, fun outdoors gastropub that serves up an eclectric menu of German favorites like Bratwurst with fresh pretzles, maple syrup bacon bread pudding and wide array of drinks. They are currently in the process of expanding the business so expect longer hours during the coming summer. My friend and I had very fortunately stumbled upon Biergarten on our way to Chantal Guillon for macaroons, while waiting to be seated for dinner. Both of us decided to return after our dinner reservation for late night (~7pm) spirits and snacks. Although they were bustling with people around dinner time, the crowd began to thin down when we got there...so there was no line and plenty of blankets, seating available. And now I can proudly say that we were very happy with this decision!

There were 2 draft beers, 2 wines offerings that evening with several snacks. We decided on a white dessert wine, Pilsner and maple syrup bacon bread pudding to share. Everything was delicious, although the bread pudding was a little burnt at the bottom. Our Pilsner was big enough to be shared between the two of us. The warmly lit ambiance and complimentary blankets offered a nice shelter against the chilly winter night, overall making the scenery extremely sweet and comfortable...to the extent in which I ended up taking a short nap amidst our talking, snacking and drinking. Overall, it was the icing on top of great evening. Even though I didn't eat here...judging by the hungry bites my fellow customers were taking, the menus would definitely be worth exploring! The portions of their entrees may not filling enough for dinner but would serve as generous snacks to pair with drinks. I would say that this is a great place to for a laid-back hangout with friends on a weekday night, after work, or weekend. Good choice! Will definitely be returning with more friends
author: Jenny Z.

description: Ive come here a few times and everytime has been great! i always run into cool people to chat with there! i love the pretzels, brats and beer! the atmmosphere is always fun, very casual and who doesnt like to drink beer outside on a beautiful day! this is the perfect place to go with friends when you are in Hayes Valley!
author: Christian D.

description: Best and pretty much only outdoor beirgarten in SF. Regardless it is awesome and a great place to meet up and hang when the whether is nice. Get there early though because it gets really crowded, especially on nice days.
author: Kyle F.

description: Very nice place to go sit and have a brew. The term "Garden" might be a little bit of an overstatement as there is only one tree, but the place makes up for it with amazing food, and quality beer! The food is classic bar food or what you would expect to find from a food stand at a beer festival. Wooden benches are limited so be sure to get there early enough to grab a table for a big group, If not everyone I met was friendly and happy to let us sit with them. Beer was all German and served in tall mugs. A great place to go during a warm SF day, as well as great lighting and atmosphere to go and enjoy a drink at night!
author: Shahin K.

description: Awesome spot to meet up with friends on a nice sunny afternoon. Beers were delicious, although I'm not usually a fan of dark beers I really liked the Four Point. The pretzel, deviled eggs and cheese knot we ordered were really delicious as well. Cool spot in a fun neighborhood with good food.
author: Daniella O.

description:
I came here on a Friday afternoon/evening and apparently I lucked out that bit was somewhat chilly because my friend and I were actually able to get a seat. I've been told this place is usually packed. 

I love the layout and vibe. It is very casual and relaxed. Get a beer, order some snacks, drink and catch up with friends. Gotta love the big steins. 

My one knock is the line to order drinks. I'm a fan of orderly single queues, like chipotle. Here there were a couple of lines, a mesh of people to together and others just lolly gagging. Make one line and it is empirically proven to be faster and more efficient. This is a win win for both consumers and the business.
author: Jee H.

description:
I'd only come here on a Wednesday or Thursday...because every other day, you're bound to wait forever in line and share communal tables with douchey peeps. 

The best food items: deviled eggs, pickled veggies, pork belly sliders and the burger. Pork belly sliders are what's up.
author: Joy A.

description: There is nothing better than sitting outside in the sunshine enjoying a giant beer. On the other hand, there is nothing like wrapping yourself up in one of their blankets and enjoying a giant beer in the cool fog of SF. Either way, Biergarten is a great place to come after a long day. It's relaxing, casual, and always a good time. LPT: get the pretzel.
author: Rachel M.

description:
On a beautiful Saturday afternoon after having spent all morning at the new Exploratorium acting like overgrown children, my group and I decided that we should reassert our adult-ness by grabbing liters of beer at the Biergarten. None of us had ever been, though we were all intrigued by the Yelp photos of mugs as big as our heads.

We got in line at about 2:45PM-2:50PM (right before they opened), and it had already just turned the corner on the block. They opened at 3PM on the dot, and people immediately either stampeded for the shady tables scattered through the courtyard or moved towards the beer line. By the time we got to the gate, most of the tables were already filled up, so we commandeered what looked like the only empty one left right by the gate itself.

Then, we waited for our beers. It took us about 30 minutes before we even got to order. Not that I ever really mind having to wait, but I should be waiting for beers that I can't find anywhere else. The beers that Biergarten had on tap were ones that you could find at most good, local liquor shops. But whatever, we were here to enjoy the Biergarten for what it was.

At $7-10 a half liter and twice that for a full liter, and with food ranging from another $4-16 (from the knots to the baskets), Boyfriend and I ran up a $42 tab for a liter and a half of beer, a frankfurter with sauerkraut and a bratwurst with curried potatoes. Everything was yummy, but not mouthwateringly rave-worthy.

Overall verdict: a very nice little spot with the potential to be very chill, but a little over-hyped. I would totally go back -- but at the prices they're charging and for what you get in return, I might just grab their beer only instead of snagging something to munch on, too.
author: Anna W.

description: What a great spot for good German beer on tap and tasty pub food...  Went here on a cold foggy night and ordered up their dopplebock and hefeweizen along with pork belly sliders (small but delicious with tender pork belly and slaw), and bratwurst and curried potatoes.  They have blankets on every picnic table to warm up those cold bodies as well...  Fun casual atmosphere...  I can just imagine this place hopping in the day when the sun is actually shining.  Will be back (probably on a sunnier day).
author: Lawrence L.

description: Food was awesome, beer amazing, service awesome, friendly opened environment. I'll be back.
author: Lauren S.

description:
Day drinking outdoors? Christmas lights and blankets after dark? I'm down. 

German bier on tap and friendly staff to explain every eccentricity and flavor profile. Bathrooms in an adjacent shipping container are always a plus.
author: Jojo H.

description:
The Cat and Fiddle in Hollywood was closed for this ?
Good Grief, prepare for a luke warm reception,

Please leave the SF superior sneer complex where it belongs...
A Pretzel will go down like a lead balloon after 32 years of neighborhood memories,

regards,
jb.
author: Jeromhia B.

description: Whether you're a local, transplant, or just visiting. The Biergarten is A MUST! They have a great variety. Try the Brass Monkey, it's like a beer-mosa and so delish. If you order the mug be warned, drunkenness is sure to follow. ;) One tip though, don't plan on this being your lunch spot. We were pretty shocked when we ordered a burger and sandwich and ended up with the tiniest sliders. So get lunch beforehand.
author: Alyse A.

description:
This place is awesome.  San Francisco is waaaaaay short on patios, so if you want to enjoy a cold beer, some snacks and a whole lot of sunshine, this is the place to do it.

Be warned there are always lineups though.  It seems intimidating, but is totally worth it.  You'll wait like 15minutes in line, don't stress, enjoy the day.  The interesting thing about this place is that you have to line up every single time you want a beer, you can't order at the tables.  What this means is that there is a pretty consistent turnover of the tables, so once you've ordered your beer, you can usually always find a place to sit.  

They are associated with Suppen Kuchen across the street, so you are guaranteed some quality in the snack foods they serve.  :)
author: Evelyn N.

description:
2 stars for the location and the fun casual ambiance.

For a beer garden, they only had 4-5 options on tap, which sucked. The snack options are limited but taste good, based on the couple of things we ordered.
author: Gaurav A.

description:
Despite the long wait to get your beer, the environment definitely makes up for it. The vibe is super chill and relaxing, mostly consisted of either people who've just got off work and people celebrating a rare sunny SF afternoon.  

Came with 7 people on a Friday afternoon, the line was already forming outside to the sidewalk by 430PM. Waited about 20 minutes in line as the others grabbed a table. Getting the table and the actual beer was both instant, which was very nice. I have yet to try the food here, but from the things I was smelling, it's definitely worth a try. 

The entire "garden" area was pretty packed the entire time, started getting pretty full by 7PM. The line for beer was against the gate, about a 35 minute wait (Don't know who would have the patience to wait that long for a beer...). The bathrooms were pretty clean (compared to your regular pub/bar around the city), ignore the men & womens signs, there's a urinal in the womens. 

The beer overall was rather tasty. I had two liters of Weihenstephaner (Keep in mind that I'm a 5'1 female, so you can imagine how much you would be able to consume!), lighter ale which totally hit the spot considering how extremely sunny it was! To me, it was worth the wait and the price. 

Definitely coming back here again! :)
author: Alyssa C.

description: Trendy spot to go if you like beer. I hate beer. I was informed they had Mulled Wine; I love Mulled Wine. When I got there, they no longer serve it. So I got a regular glass of white. It was disappointing; very small amount served in a crappy little water glass. Service wasn't that great. Guy behind the counter wasn't friendly either. Don't think I will go back unless a group of people want to go and I have to go. Don't think I will get anymore wine though. I'll just get Smitten Ice Cream next door.
author: R M.

description: Super packed, decent vibes, high prices, but pretty decent product. Nothing amazing but a decent place to have a drink on a nice day (if you can even find a seat).
author: Ian S.

description:
Cool outdoor beer garden in a great location. There are not many options for outdoor drinking in the city so this is a great addition right in the heart of Hayes Valley.

There are three German beers on tap ranging from $6 to $9 for half liters and $12 to $18 for liters. There are plenty more bottles available if the beers on tap don't do it for you.

Although when they first opened they did not have many food options they seem to have added to the menu. They have lots of small foods (pretzels, deviled eggs, chive bread, etc) to keep the beer company in your stomach. German sausages are also available if you want something larger but I wouldn't recommend coming here if you are looking for a meal though.

The line consistently looks long but it goes by really fast (5-10 minutes) and you can hop in line before you finish your last beer so you never go thirsty. The major downside is that it is not a very large place and the seating is limited so it can be tough to find a place to sit on a nice day, especially if you are in a group.

Clean bathrooms, pretty cool staff, descent crowd the times I went. Also, they have blankets to give out to people when the weather gets colder.
author: Frank J.

description: If you're looking for mediocre beer, gruff service, tiny food portions and unpretentious surroundings with pretentious prices then you've found the spot! If not, and you're looking for good food, good service and good prices with a beer garden, check out zeitgeist instead.
author: Chad T.

description:
I actually really like this place, but the hassle of getting either beer or food makes it just okay. 

Pros:
- Great location
- Outside atmosphere
- Great beer & Decent Food

Cons: 
- Time spent standing in line
- Time spent away from the rest of your party standing in line
- Time spent with the rest of your party standing in line
- No pets (but I don't hold this against them, every business gets to choose their preference)
author: Luke O.

description:
Depending on the type of beer you choose a 1/2 liter can be anywhere from $6-8.  Their beer selection is limited in comparison to Suppenkuche but the Schneider weisse hits the spot. 

Bratwurst basket is perfect for two ($18): one sausage for each of you, a pretzel to share, and for dipping - horseradish (that WILL clear up your nose) and brown mustard. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/GfeaoeKtZh-57SFWgjPqnw?select=eFrF65UAqKeei47XHGh8oA)

The place is crowded, but as long as you are willing to make friends and share tables, it's great fun especially on a sunny Saturday afternoon.
author: Kimya P.

description: Great place to come on a nice sunny day. Got here just before the post work rush. Great location in Hayes valley and next to smitten ice cream which I love. Got the radler and was great and refreshing on a hot day. Would definitely come back. Had some good beers on tap as well and food!
author: Emily F.

description:
I like the idea of ordering a large beer, some fried pickles, and sitting outside in the middle of the city for some excellent conversation and people watching.

Biergarten is the perfect place to drink quality beer in large amounts and not have to deal with the "scene" of most beer bars these days.

Check it out.
author: Justin R.

description: Great beer but a lot of crowding. I would recommend getting there early if you are a large group. The pretzel and deviled eggs are yum!
author: Vanessa H.

description:
fun time to eat/drink with old friends and make new ones

waited out the line til opening which seems to be the pattern, at least its not the hurry up to wait scene

was able to leverage other half of table to a group of 4 that was kind enough to let us add on to their beer order which is key as the line recycles for rd 2.  like a new D1 recruiting class they move on as a set of friendly ivy educated gals who work private equity sit down and laugh at our dumb jokes.  this city is diverse alright

the pretzel, sliders, pickled eggs and veggies were great.  both dames and dudes restrooms have urinals 

people are friendly (staff / patrons) as its hard to be mean nor grumpy drinkin beer out of giant gustos while baskin in the sun

get your people together and head over
author: Clark G.

description:
Got there on a Saturday at 6:30 PM. The line to buy your drink was long. Took about 20-30 minutes. Good German beer at a decent price. I had friends there already so I didn't have to find a seat, but from what I noticed, it's not that hard to get a seat around the time that I went even though the line to buy beer took a while.

One thing though: it was hella cold! They give out some thick fleece/woolish blankets once the sun starts to set. However, they may feel kind of grimey as you do not know who else used the them and how often they were washed.

Some heat lamps would've definitely made the experience 1 star better
author: Ray Z.

description: I loved the relax atmosphere. Perfect place for Friday to start the weekend. And the food was delicious! Our friends told us it was great, and it definitely net up to its review!!
author: Christine H.

description: My husband and I came with our 5 month old daughter to meet some friends. We were in need of an emergency diaper change and the workers there were promptly there to help us out. They don't have a changing area but we made do with their help! Excellent customer service. We THOROUGHLY appreciated it. Good wine, beer and snacks too!
author: Jojo S.

description: What an excellent place! The bier is great! The food looked good (I'd had lunch before I found this place). I loved the vibe! The place was packed & I could see why. Biergarten's are great for meeting other people due to the communal seating which is cool if you are a visitor. Clean & neat & a very friendly staff. Prost!
author: RJ S.

description:
We visited Biergarten during quite cold weather, so we didn't have to wait in the legendary lines. The beer was awesome, as was all the food. Pretzels, mustard, pickles, sandwiches... yummmmm.

A fabulous time was had by all. Love that they provide blankets!!
author: Emily M.

description:
Be prepared to wait in a very long line ... 

This place is amazing!  And outdoor beer garden is just an awesome place to hang out and drink and have a great time with friends.  We arrived around 3pm and realized that there was already a long line that had formed to get in.  Apparently, you have to go earlier than that to stand in line. 

It took us about 45 minutes to one hour before we got to the front to order and sit down.  There are limited tables and the service can be a little slow.  Not sure why they don't have separate lines for drinks only and drinks/food.  I think that was what was slowing down the line.  Plus, once you get in it might be tough to find a table as most of the tables get filled up quickly.  You might have to squeeze with other people but it makes it more fun. 

We ordered a cheese pretzel to try their handmade pretzels and it was delicious!  If I had room for more food, I would've ordered more just to try everything out.  You can order different sizes for the beer so don't be scared off by the large giant mugs everyone is carrying around.  Or you might be get really excited seeing them.  

Either way this is a really nice place to just sit, enjoy your beer and chat the night away.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Beergarden...I mean, Biergarten has a great concept. Outdoor drinking, large mugs, and German eats.

It's a great way to spend a sunny afternoon in the city with some good company. The German beers come in this huge mug which is a cool idea. The beer was tasty, but if you like real beer I would recommend staying away from the beer mixed with the soda. By the halfway mark, the sweetness gets to you and it's harder to drink by the minute. 

Beware that the line can get VERY long and unfortunately, it's the same line if you want another round. Ain't nobody got time for that! Maybe it's their way of crowd control so that there is not one group that stays forever unless they are really determined to wait in that line again. How do you not wait in line? Show up when Biergarten opens. There will be no line to wait in and a hopefully somewhat short one for seconds.

Unique beer, beautiful day, great company...good times.
author: David P.

description:
In summary, there's really nothing better than being with friends under the perfect sunset after a long day of work enjoying an ice cold one and a pretzel.

Sorry, minus one star for not wanting to stand in the long line again for a refill on the beer. 
Well, on to the next watering hole...
author: Jeremy F.

description:
Hier ist mein lieblings kneipe!  Ich habe das Bier und der Lebensmittel sehr gern. ;)

Haha Ok just kidding, I won't attempt a German review... Yes, this really is my favorite hangout after work because it's outside and the beer and food rocks!  The people that work here are super nice, the bathrooms are clean (plus it's a good idea to have storage containers for restrooms) and lastly, the atmosphere is great.  Everyone looks like they're having a great time and I love bringing people here.

Super 5 star bonus earner:  Even if it's cold outside, thank you for providing plenty of warm blankets!  Now that's taking care of your customers!
author: Nic E.

description:
If the weather's nice and you want to just chill with some friends, you should definitely come here! But make sure you come early, it gets packed QUICK. I like the beer selection and the mugs they're served in. Brass Monkey was particularly delicious - taste like straight up OJ but the buzz totally creeped up on me!

It's a little pricey ($8 for a small and $16 for a large) but the environment's chill and it's exactly what you need if you ever want to remind yourself that you're in San Francisco. 

Stay away from the pretzels.
author: V L.

description: Went there with girlfriends. The beer was fine, the food was also fine but the ambience was not too enjoyable in the foggy chilly area like SF.
author: Joelle K.

description: One of my favorite places to go in the city for an outdoor beer.  The food is amazing also so don't forget to grab a brat or pretzel!  They have blankets available if you are worried it may be too cold.  An SF must stop for any tourist.
author: Casey L.

description: Great beer place that provides blankets but the food prices are outrageous.
author: Magda G.

description:
Did you wake up this A.M. imagining yourself with some friends on a big picnic table hugging a liter krug (that's German for big ass 1 person pitcher) of a Suppenkuche beer?

Well this lil Beer Garden / Reclaimed Parking Lot complete with retrofitted industrial shipping containers is Das Shizzy! It's overflowing with all the reasons people love Suppenkuche without having to elbow wrestle yourself a beer.

Not only is it bad ass man sized beers, they got some dang good grub to boot! Like pretzels, brats, salads, and sliders! You see they've built one of the old shipping containers into a kitchen. Genius! Then they built onto it a little back patio with a fire grill. Brilliant!

Now throw in some sunny weather and you've got an afternoon of the Gods that is till one of the crazy locals decides to cozy up on your bench and kill your buzz but hey at least they're staying true to the German culture and leaving the choice of where to sit the toughest choice of all!
author: R J.

description:
Atrocious service. It took 1 hour 15 standing in line to get a beer, so we each stocked up on 2 litres when we did get served. SF lacks nice places like this to sit outside in the sun and drink a beer, and they are taking advantage of this fact. 

When I arrived at the bar they were out of 1L glasses, but more were coming from the dishwasher. The barman twiddled his thumbs for 3 minutes, waiting for the glasses, and not serving anyone else. It seems like they are doing their very best to be as slow as possible. And then they expect a tip!

I'm Irish, so I know effective bar service and the duty a barman has not to make people wait. Employing some general efficiency in your work is a good start. And processing more than one order at a time is effective too; does however require the brainpower to remember more than one drink order. These people show neither interest in happy customers, nor even in making more money quicker for the owners or tips for themselves. Disgraceful. I won't be back. It's run even worse than its sister restaurant Suppenküche.
author: Ronan B.

description:
This is a great place for a BIG group.  With the long outdoor benches, and the restaurant-provided placards, this is a great place for a meetup.

They have a good variety of beers on tap and knowledgable people to serve them up.  Still, the variety isn't as large as expected considering the title.  The food selection is not large, and the atmosphere beerhall, not intimate in any way shape or form.  Also the lines can be long.

The great thing about it is that you are offered tiny beer tastings (like a sample spoon at an ice cream shop).
author: Laura A.

description:
Biergarten is super yummy! The beer is great and served in large quantities and the food is delicious. 

I'm a huge fan of the meat and cheese pretzel knots. Oh and the bratwurst is so good --- the mustard and sauerkraut served with it is fantastic. Also, homemade pickles and pickled carrots and the horseradish...drooling just thinking about it. 

Spend some time outside and enjoy what Beirgarten has to offer. I challenge you to not have a good time :P 

Next stop is the sister restaurant Suppenküche.
author: Tysen C.

description:
You gotta ask yourself one question. "Do I feel like getting wasted?" Well do ya? Punks! 

The biergarten is a great place for someone to get hammered. Just kidding. The line itself takes about 45 minutes so naturally the first question I asked myself was "2 steins or 1." It's very important you see because 2 balances the very fine art of being happy and off your chair hammered and 1 is "oh i am definitely going to be sober by the time i get my second one."

I opted for two steins. It was an absolutely wonderful decision and the sun was shining brighter than it had before I started drinking. 

So point of the story. Don't be a wuss and double fist some steins. I promise it isn't lonely on the floor. 

Five stars for atmosphere (cute as hell), beers, food, bathrooms (so cute). Minus one for the line that put me in that awful 2v1 predicament in the first place.
author: Jenny C.

description:
if the weather is nice, then this is a great place to come and hang out...the beer selection could grow, they only had 3 types of beers when we went, but they were pretty good. We had the tacos...which seem an odd choice for a beer garden, but they were actually delicious. 
The place seems to always be crowded, so finding a seat may be a bit of a challenge sometimes, but definitely a place worth checking out.
author: George M.

description:
On warm, sunny days (the few that SF sees), you'll find Biergarten packed -- so packed that the line to get beer wraps around the block! But in the end, very few things bring as much joy as a liter of good beer with friends in the sunshine. In my book, all the beers are delightful. The razzler (a lemonade and beer mix) is a bit sweet and doesn't have enough alcohol content for me. Yes, this little girl CAN drink :)

Tip #1: If your doom is to wait in a line that wraps around the block (and I've been there before), make your time efficient by grabbing some snack foods from the snack stand (like a pretzel - they're pretty delicious) to make the wait go by faster. Also, waiting in line with friends is always a plus.

Tip #2: If you see that you have about a third of your liter beer left and you feel a tingling sensation in your bladder, be efficient with your time and drink the rest of your beer while you wait in line for the restroom. Sometimes the line for the restroom exceeds the line for beer!

Tip #3: SF weather is fickle. At 3:00, it may seem all sunshiny and warm, but when 5:30 rolls around, it'll be gray and cold, so be prepared and come with a jacket. If you forget and the beer isn't helping you keep warm, Biergarten staff goes around, handing out blankets! How awesome is that?!?!

Tip #4: Don't skimp on the beer. Order a liter (never the half) . . . you DID just probably wait 15-30 mins for it anyway. Make your suffering worth it.
author: Linna L.

description: I had a beer and pretzel at the Biergarten -- both of which were good. It was packed, hot, and tough to find a spot to sit, which wasn't ideal, but I do think it's a good place for a group of friends to check out at one point or another. The barbed wire fence and concrete create a slightly weird vibe -- hoping they rennovate eventually!
author: Lauren L.

description: I love this place! Chill outdoor seating, a few beers to choose from in a 1/2 or 1 liter, excellent saurkraut and sausages, and a perfect happy hour spot with friends. I only wish they had more seating as sometimes it can get so packed and you have no where to sit but on a sunny day in SF, this is perfect.
author: Madeline S.

description:
We were on our way to Smitten and stumbled across this little gem. Even though I had given up beer (well, newly given up as a month and a half ago) and a most of us didn't drink beer, I am SO glad we did anyways! It's such a cute idea and would be an awesome place to hang out and catch up with friends in the summer. It was still winter though and a little chilly at 4PM in the afternoon, but hey. When in SF.... do what San Franciscians do right? 

We waiting probably a little over half an hour to make our way to the front. The girl pouring our beer was super nice and knowledgable and informed us of the different brews they had on draft. We even got to sample a few of them! I forgot which one we got, but it was tasty. Two size options: A liter or a half. With my newly found appreciation for clean eating and giving up beer, I opted for the half. Wise choice on my behalf. *Pats on back*

By the time we all got our beers and wine, a table opened up. Score! Then it got chilly the longer we stayed out there. Probably around 5PM. The nice lady that worked there asked us if we wanted blankets. YES! Double score! 

Definitely an awesome place to check out!
author: Ling H.

description:
Pickled deviled eggs.

I don't even like anything pickled or pickles but these were glorious. They had some kind of butter spread on top - pretty sure that's what made them as glorious as they were. Do not miss out on these.

Sidenote: first time ever having deviled eggs. I'm not ashamed to admit that, okay?!
author: Jonny A.

description:
Love this place! The reason I only give 4 stars is due to the extremely long lines. Buy the biggest beer you can because you won't want to get back in line! 

I recommend coming here on a nice day because everything is outside with little shade and no overhangs. They have a great German beer selection and a small menu with daily specials! I tried the Beet salad which was very tasty and generous size. I also tried the Pork belly sliders, amazing! 

I came here with a group of friends, we all showed up a different times and had to stand in line for over a 1/2 hour. We never went back for seconds because the line never died down. 

Overall, great weekend day drinking spot!
author: Julie J.

description:
Outdoor drinking!  Gets very packed.  But it is a great social atmosphere with communal picnic bench seating.

Get: 
The 1L Beer.  The line gets long and isn't that quick, so you want to minimize your visits.

Frankfurt Special - Skinny sausage on  a pretzel bun with a pile of sauerkraut, jalapeño slices, and mustard.
author: Steven F.

description:
Pros: delicious beer, good food, cool mugs, sun!, chill atmosphere.
Cons: long line for food/beer and expensive

We went there on a Sunday afternoon. They open at 1:00 so we got there at 1:15 ish to get a picnic table. You definitely need to get there by 1:30 if you want a table. The line for beer/food at that time was about a 10 minute wait. There is only one line and one bar. The line later in the day got to be about 25 minutes. The first time we got small beers ($8) because we were afraid the big ones would get warm. Second time around we got the large beers ($16) and dealt with the warming of the beer under the lovely sun.  Will definitely we back on the next warm, sunny day.
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
Great place to drink with your friends on a sunny afternoon. Everyone's friendly, especially drunk on German beer! If it gets cold, large blankets are provided.

My friends and I have tried pints of different flavors of beer and they're all good. My wife's favorite is the pork belly sliders, even though the bratwurst is my favorite.

The lines can get extremely long on hotter days, but it's worth the wait if you have a friend or two to save some seats. We always try to make our way to Biergarten on warm weekends!

Plus: bathrooms on the back left!
author: LA H.

description:
Great spot to catch up with friends.  Chilly weather may thin the crowds slightly but the place was still packed around 7pm.  The half liter of Schneider Edel-Weisse hits the spot - very smooth and filling. 

Haven't tried the food yet but will get there.
author: F. P.

description:
If you ever want to see the worst side of human existence...come to this place, especially on a weekend or a sunny day...or worst yet both combined.

The crowd is unbearable in its homogenous selection of entitled and rude 20-40 something nerd alerts with absolutely no visual interest but an overwhelming lack of awareness....uh, huh IT IS THAT BAD.  

My sausage was cold.  The server was cool but he too seemed unable to do much about the two jerks who sat at a table, with no beer or food.  NOTE TO SERVER: THIS IS WHEN YOU WIPE DOWN THE TABLE REPEATEDLY AND OR REMOVE EMPTY GLASSES OR GENTLY ASK IF THEY ARE WAITING FOR SOMEONE IN LINE.

The place sucks, 
The wait sucks (why am I here again?),
The crowd sucks,
The food is alright,
And after waiting patiently in line for an hour, shame on you register guy for being a dick about my questions regarding the food.  Clearly someone missed orientation and felt flustered by a few simple question.
author: StudioCollette M.

description: A very solid Beer Garden with very good beer.  Went here with a group of 10 friends to celebrate a birthday.  We got there after the rest of the group, so they already had a table and were pretty far up in line.  That being said, it is busy on a Saturday afternoon in the fall and the line moves very slowly.  Had we not taken turns waiting in line, the experience would have been a lot less enjoyable.  But it's a beer garden and we got exactly what we expected - overly large beers, German food, and nice outdoor seating.
author: Alex O.

description:
I came to Biergarten for a quick bite but quickly made friends in the outdoor friendly atmosphere.  I ordered the bratwurst with a tangy sauerkraut and spicy brown mustard on pretzel bread.  When my sausage arrived it protruded out of both sides of the short pretzel bun, which kind of reminded me of the Scandinavian hot-dogs.  This allowed me to taste the meat, which was very tasty.  I was pleased to find the heaping amount of sauerkraut on top and paired with the mustard and freshly baked pretzel bun I was in heaven.  

I'm sad to say I didn't stay long enough to grab a beer but the selection looked more than adequate and I'm sure would go very well with the food.  I'll be back to try something else and drink up for last time!
author: Natan O.

description:
My favorite beer garden in the city.  On one of those rare sunny days we enjoy in the city, this is where you can find me. The main event is of course the bier, which you can get in either a half pint size or a 1 liter size (stein). There isn't a huge selection of beers, maybe 5 or 6, and I always get the wheat Schneider Edel-Weisse. There is also a few options when it comes to food fare. There are pickles, bratwursts, frankfurts, pretzels and pork belly sliders. The sliders are outrageously delicious, I highly suggest you order them.

The beer garden is set up with a bunch of cafeteria style lunch tables. It can be hard to find a spot to sit on a busy weekend. On colder days, they offer blankets for customers.
author: Derrek O.

description: A blacktop surrounded by a chain-link fence? Is that your idea of a biergarten? Spend one day at a biergarten in Germany, and this place looks like a cheap attempt to attract a hipster crowd. But I wouldn't be writing this review if it weren't for the fact that you could not bring outside food in. You have two food trucks and some picnic tables, let a man eat his Ike's sandwich in peace!
author: Pat W.

description:
What an awesome place to spend a chill afternoon sipping on some beer, or for some full on day drinking! 

This little outdoor beer garden is located in Hayes Valley, right next to a little park with a playground. Almost makes you feel like you're in a suburb, and not right in the middle of the city!

We came on a sunny Sunday afternoon a couple minutes after they opened. The line was relatively short and a couple tables were free. After we sat down though, the place started to fill up FAST! Before long, there were people standing around waiting for tables, and the line was out the entrance! I suggest trying to come as close to opening as possible, cause this place gets packed.

The beers they have are unique and tasty, and are fairly priced. They offer half and full liter glasses. I didn't get the chance to sample the food, the pretzels looked amazing! Maybe next time...
author: Sally T.

description:
4+.
Good beer, good to awesome food (pink deviled eggs! and sunflower-seed pretzels with fresh horseradish, etc.) The salad basket is a real bargain.

Today they had a somewhat interesting ice-sculpture that everyone was instagraming. Hipster and self-aware? Hell yeah, and I don't care. I can ignore them as easily as I can ignore anyone else. They are somewhat quietly loathing themselves while I am quietly enjoying my food. It's a win-win in out parallel universes. An occasional neutrino upsets the balance.
author: michaelangela v.

description: Nice place to grab a beer. And try their potatoes and pretzel. FYI outside seats only
author: Yifan W.

description:
So much love for this place. It's basically my backyard. The food is fantastic (I prefer the alarmingly pink deviled eggs, and the pretzel-wich with brie and picked shallots), the bathrooms are some of the cleanest I've *ever* seen (tip: they're marked as Mens and Womens in name only so no worries using the other gender's bathroom for efficiency's sake.) Oh yeah, and they have beer, too! Lots and lots of lovely delicious beer.

The only thing I could possibly ask for is more beer options. And earlier opening hours. And some chairs for lounging with a book. Just small things.
author: Connor Skye R.

description: Great for a sunny day. Great beer. The hotdog mustard was below standard for a German spot. The pool sliders were their hit. The banana knot was meh
author: andrew l.

description:
Biergarten is quite an amazing find. Whoever thought of this concept is pretty genius. Perfect on a sunny day and of course I went during the coldest/cloudiest/windiest days ever, but those 1L beers make up for anything short of having a good time. 

Grab a bunch of buddies, get 1L beers, a big pretzel each, and drink your miseries away! Bathroom is pretty fancy porta-potty with a shared sink complete with mirror. Communal picnic benches that you can easily swoop by busting out your eagle eyes. 

P.S. Bring a jacket. Biergarten, can you get some heat lamps up in there?!
author: Tracy T.

description:
One of my favorite bars in SF!

On a sunny day, this place can't be beat. It also reminds me of biergartens when I lived in Berlin. You order your food at the window and take it back to your communal picnic table. I always order litres or else I'd be made fun of. $16 for a litre of most beers and $8 for .5. They also bring in food from Suppenküche from down the street. That's a huge plus.

The only drawback is the huge line. Since the place opens at 3:00pm, the line usually wraps around the corner by 2:50pm. The longest part of getting your drink will be waiting in line. If you come closer to sunset (also when it's colder), you'll get your drinks faster. Good luck coming on a warm and sunny day ~ even though these are the best days to come.

Last but not least, the bathrooms are actually very nice for a bar. Surprising how they can repurpose old shipping containers to be so cool.
author: Paul B.

description: Baby became cranky when they couldn't get into Suppenkuche.  So, they brought baby to the biergarten for brats and beer. Daddy chugged down a lager.  Mommy wolfed down the pretzel.  They shared a basket of sauerkraut, bratwurst, and yes, another pretzel.  Baby didn't get brats or beer, but fell asleep dreaming about them, so Mommy and Daddy were extra happy, too.
author: Peg S.

description:
Loved it!

4-5 taps of German beer. A little pricey but oh-so-good. Bartenders were very nice. Great that they accept credit cards. 

We managed to find a table pretty easily on a Friday afternoon (4th of July weekend). One of the girls in our group ordered the pretzel knot with cheese and it looked SO good. We were getting dinner at Suppenkuche later on that night or else I would've ordered some food. It all looked quite good.

Will come back again! It was so cold this time, but maybe next time I'll pay Smitten a visit too!
author: Emily H.

description:
First off, I wished I wasn't stuffed before I came here because the food looked and smelled awesome.

If you like your German Beers then this place will work for you. Biergarten is simply cool. The only downside is the general frigidness of S.F. 

I'm only giving it four stars for the lack of space heaters. I only left because my face was frozen.
author: Keith A.

description:
Um, hello! I don't know why this place doesn't have a perfect score! It is awesome!  We rode our bikes down here and arriving at 5:30, were able to score an end of a table and some great beer!  Don't forget about the regular pretzel!  The spicy mustard with horseradish is to die for! I can't wait to go back!

The blankets make it!  SF can get cold in a blink of an eye but their blankets make everything alright!
author: Vanessa L.

description: Get your dranken on! A nice day in Sacramento can turn a little chilly in SF. I was in the area and was looking for a place for lunch and a good buzz. Biergarten is mostly outdoors. I love how their facilities are shipping containers. A container for the kitchen, a container for the bathroom, one for the bar. The German themed establishment had beers I've never had or even heard of. I love beer, Biergarten has beer, I love Biergarten! I got my nephew an almdudler which was pretty good too. Tastes like lemon soda, but gooooood lemon soda. The sea dog was really good. A long weiner nestled between a soft warm hearty bun with bacon, masago, and some white stuff on top. The devilled eggs, curry potatoes, n pork belly sliders were forgettable. I wish they could lower their prices a little and figure out the parking situation better. Overall this place is GREAT!!
author: Tri V.

description: Fun spot in the middle of Hayes Valley.  The beer (tried the Helles) was delicious and comes in sizes of 0.5 or 1 L depending on how big you want to go ;) The food menu is full of fun, creative bites.  The line to get beer does get pretty long when it's crowded (aka any semi-sunny afternoon), but the bartenders are all friendly and take the time to tell you about the beers and sample different types regardless.  Fun place for groups & perfect to wander around Hayes before or after.
author: Raina D.

description:
This is exactly what you hope for and expect at a limited hours outdoor beer-drinking venue. It's roots are clearly German, offering schnitzel and steins of German beers with soft pretzels and artisan mustard, however it's spirit is clearly influenced by the happy-go-lucky drinking mentality of San Francisco that just so happens to have the limited days and hours of whenever it feels like and early.

Great spot, wish it was more available to people in the industry or people who don't go to bed at 8pm.
author: Heather W.

description: I get my New Orleans style iced coffee, do some shopping in the neighborhood and then after playing with dogs in the park come here for a pint or two and some super good sliders! This is the spot, great people come here and everyone becomes friends at the picnic tables which are always seating, even strangers don't mind leg over lap of each other to squeeze as many people in.
author: Dove N.

description: This place is legit.  It is what you would expect for great german beer and bratwurst.  They have the Hofbrau classic beer served in the HB german bubble glass steins (1/2 and full liters).  The only problem is that this place is always crowded, which is good for business, but hard to find a seat.  Good atmosphere, and a great place to stop for a beer if the lines are short, and there are several nice eateries in the local area if you aren't in the mood for a wiener.
author: Dan M.

description:
The prices, unfortunately, are entirely off the mark for my liking. For the price of a liter of beer, I'd rather go back to Germany and buy it there.

Also, I was very sad that the potato salad was mayo-based.
author: Joshua O.

description:
Awesome place! No indoor sitting - just picnic tables and blankets (ask for them if it's cold and windy!!!) with an usually enormous line for the beer and food. 

Usually when there's a long wait, it almost always deters me from liking a place as much. Something about Biergarten doesn't do that. Good large beers, good yummy snacks - try to take turns standing in lines, because there's no table service, so you have to go back into line everytime. A great place to just chill with some beers and some food and chill in the sunshine
author: Lena Y.

description:
Recommended by friend while in SF.

Quality of food/bev (8/10). Relative value (9/10). They basically sell you a liter of beer for $12. How many beers in a liter?
http://wiki.answers.com/Q/How_many_beers_in_a_liter

That comes out to about $4.00 per beer. That's a pretty good value. Plus it looks pretty cool hoisting those oversize beer steins.

Ambience: This place is basically an empty lot covered in black asphalt and park benches (rumored to have been flown in straight from Germany). The two buildings are basically converted storage containers. You sit where you can, and usually random people share tables. Me likey as fun social place.

They day we went there was also a band playing dressed in funny german outfits. I heard they volunteer and get paid in beer. 

Only four beers on tap and very limited menu, but if you're going to be picky about those types of things, go to a sit down resturatant or the Yard House.

I'd probably give this 4.5 stars mainly for the value, and the social aspect of this place. Fun times.
author: Noodle S.

description:
We went with a crew a few weeks ago.  It's good and I know it will probably get better.  So far the outdoor situation and tables are great and the location is a perfect idea.  Pretzels are yummy.  Kraut is tasty.  Food comes fast.  Mmmmmustard.  I like that they used container ship crates as their workspaces.  Park across the street for kids and kids are even allowed in!  And beer, who doesn't go to a biergarten and like that?!

Things that need tweeking are...

Waitressing - it needs to exist, so far it didn't

More glasses (or 2 dishwashers, haha) - they were hovering the tables for any glassware anyone would give up

The beer lineup was retarded!  Too too too long.  If oom pah pah places all over the world can supply beer to your table in several minutes then it must be able to happen here too.  My suspicion is that the human line acts as a free visual ad aid for Biergarten as the public goes by - like, "ooh, what is that over there?? It must be popular... such a massive lineup!!  Let's go see!"

Maybe they should think about installing more beer pull taps - there are only 4 and the person taking your money is also the person pouring your beer - just takes toooo long.

ID needs to be checked at the entrance rather than every single time you go through the beer lineup.  They can make high/low stamps or whatever other idea there might be but something better.  As of now we were sending one person up to get beers for all of us - so each time a person went up to buy beer that person had to bring an ID up for each beer that was purchased - awkward and long-handed. 

I believe it can happen!  I have hope.
author: Dizzy L.

description:
Pro tip: on a night when the Hayes Valley Off the Grid pod is set up just on the other side of the fence (http://offthegridsf.com/pods), the kind folks at Biergarten will allow you to enjoy your food truck grub on their turf as long as you purchase some beers. 

And, quite frankly, why wouldn't you when presented with such an opportunity?

Long live Proxy SF! http://proxysf.net/
author: Anna G.

description: A gem in the city, delicious beers and foods. On a beautiful San Francisco day it doesn't get any better than this!
author: Sneakrs 1.

description: Right next to Smittens,.. after your dessert friends get their share of ice cream,.. walk on over to the outdoor Biergarten.  They do not have a big selection of beer,. but what makes this place stand out is the outdoor wooden bench seating.  A place to hang out, have good conversations, relax and decide on what to do next for the day/night.
author: Chanel L.

description:
The idea is great but execution is poor. The beer is the best part, quality beer and you can get a liter glass, great!

But with only 4 taps operated by 2 servers the line quickly gets crazy and makes a 35min wait for a beer. 

They need to have 4 times the number of taps and servers.

While the beer line is long and snaking outside, the food line is non-existent. Then there is a poor decision that all food must be ordered from the bar (the big line). BUT somehow you can pay cash and get a pretzel. Huh?!?!

One should be able to order food from the food cart without having to do it through the bar. Thats just plain silly.

I want to like this place but management needs to get their act together cause otherwise its a poor experience.
author: Cody C.

description:
What's good: drinking in the sunshine, pink deviled eggs, getting slightly buzzed and ordering in an obnoxoious fake German accent and annoying the shit out of the nice hipster wait staff. Hipster mustache bingo. 

Why I won't go back soon:  45 minutes in line for a beer. Das ist nicht gil. Das ist shit man.
author: Carla G.

description:
You can probably find me here on any given Saturday afternoon. The bier is good. The atmosphere is cool. The prices are moderate. 

Sadly I have yet to try the food. I always end up getting filled up on bier and decide to stumble across the street to Smitten for an ice cream dinner.
author: Eduardo R.

description:
The beer selection is very limited, but the ones I tried were delicious.  The prices for a 1L serving are pretty spendy, though, so I suggest asking to taste first if you're not familiar with the beers to ensure you like what you're getting.

So far I've only tried a few things from the kitchen, but everything I've tried was really good.  The pickles and deviled eggs were great snacks (though I'm not really sure I'm feeling the bright pink dye (beets?) on the eggs).  Sausages were delicious too. 

Service is quick though the lines are usually pretty long.  Other patrons have been really friendly about sharing the limited number of tables.  They have heavy blankets for colder days and nights. How cool is that?

My only complaints are that it does get VERY crowded.  You can end up waiting for 15+ minutes to get a drink, and even longer to snag a table.  I wish their opening hours weren't so limited, as it's tough to get a group together while they're open.  Finally, they don't allow smoking.  Not a big deal for me, as I don't smoke, but it's yet another reason I have trouble convincing friends to come here.  Sometimes we wonder why we didn't just go to Zeitgeist..
author: Heidi M.

description: Biers are very expensive ($9 for a pint?), but good. Only in SF could a bunch of shipping containers on a gravel lot be an acceptable bar. Staff is surly, will yell at you for using e-cigs, outside.
author: Nawlins B.

description:
We walked by here on the way to Smitten's across the street and knew that we had to check this place out. It's an old parking lot decked out with shipping containers that have been converted into food/beverage stands.

I had the Hefeweizen. My friend ordered some deviled eggs, along with a small bottle of some novelty German drink called Underberg. I have to say that Underberg is probably one of the nastiest drinks I've ever tried, it tasted like an alcoholic version of some potent Chinese herbal medicine. The eggs were dyed a bright, artificial pink, not too sure what the point of this was aside from wow factor. They were darn tasty though. Beer was good as well.

It's always nice to be able to enjoy beer outside, although it was pretty chilly that day. We did notice that the employees were handing out blankets to whoever wanted to bundle up some more. Very thoughtful.
author: Kevin N.

description:
Went to our neighborhood pop-up pub with some friends and all the children.  Waited in line for about 10 which was fine because the weather was gorgeous and it was fairly easy to find a table albeit shared with another couple but why not?  Always fun doing things communal.  My 7 month old, (yes, I brought the baby to a pub) was totally enjoying all the surrounding attention and the sound his wooden spoon made on the picnic table. 

Had a dark ale and the Wednesday burger special (divine) while my hubbs had some sort of mushroom cheese bread and the beets.  Why are pickled things so tasty?  Our friends woofed down the pretzels and sausage and the kiddos had pork sliders. All in all, perfect early dinner place and easy going vibe.  This is another reason why I love living in Hayes.
author: Meghan C.

description:
I was disappointed in this place; it was way overpriced ($5 for a PRETZEL?, $8 for a beer?), way overhyped (line to get in!), and food and drink that is much better done elsewhere.

Oh you just finished your beer at Biergarten and want another one?  Well, you gotta get up from your table, then stand in a long line for about 10-15 minutes just to buy your ass another beer.  There is an ARMY of staff waiting around to snatch your empty food baskets as SOON as you finish eating, but they apparently can't bring you a fresh beer (like they can in a REAL German biergarten).  Hey, let me finish the last bits of kraut before you yank that basket away, will ya?

They have a handful (3-4) of German beers on tap that you can get in massive-sized glasses if you want (bitte, $15!).  Toronado and Rosamunde Sausage Grill (the one on Mission) have the same or better selection of these types of German beers.  Even The Uptown on Capp St. usually has some nice Paulaners.

As for the food, the sausage was undercooked (still pink on the inside!) and didn't even come with a bun -- for $9!.  Rosamunde Sausage Grill's sausage is ten times better at 2/3 the price.  Heck, Rosamunde's BUN is by itself better than anything I had at Biergarten.

Aside from offering opportunity to drink outside like Zeitgeist, which frankly does everything much better (upscale people are just afraid of the bathrooms there), this place offers nothing.  This is just another overhyped pseudo foodie place in SF.  

You can find me at Rosamunde when I want a German sausage and a German beer (yes, they often even have Kostrizter Schwartzbier).  It's better (the kraut is even better, nicely seasoned with juniper berries), cheaper, and less hassle, and no wait to get in, no ridiculous 15-20 minute line to buy another beer.   The Mission location even has outside seating.

Biergarten is proof that you can take mediocre food, a handful of common German beers that are available elsewhere, overprice it all by 50% and STILL have people lining up because you put the whole thing outside -- on a slab of parking lot asphalt surrounded by a chainlink fence.  "Oh, we have a biergarten in SF... how Europeannnnnn!"
author: Paul S.

description:
Came here sometime last fall with my friends who wanted to check it out.  The concept of the place is cool; they try to replicate the atmosphere of a German beer garden with authentic benches and mugs.  They even have blankets out; a good amenity to have given the chilly nights in San Francisco.

However, in terms of their food and drink, I have mixed feelings.  In all honesty, the food there is overpriced.  I ordered the bratwurst with sauerkraut; the food was really good, however they should at least give two brats instead of only one if they charge $9.  The sauerkraut was one of the best i've ever tried... not like your typical type found at ballparks.  My friend ordered the egg sandwich (costing $8) , and he was still hungry after finishing it.
On the other hand, their beers are moderately priced. A 1/2 liter will cost you around $6-8, and they have a good selection of beers. I tried the Stiegl Pilsner and it was great!

All in all, this place is definitely worth trying at least once, just pick an evening/night that's not too cold.
author: Ryan C.

description: Such a fun place to hang out with friends or meet new ones! Especially nice on a sunny day. Downsides are the INSANELY long line to get in and the fact that there are way more people than seats. Aside from that, love the vibe and enjoy the drinks (even if they are overpriced).
author: Victoria W.

description: Was walking around the Hayes neighborhood and after eating at Smitten Ice Cream, stumbled upon the pre-grand opening of Biergarten. This location is more like a beer stand/food stand where there are tables you can sit out outside. They are suppose to open sometime next week. Also found out it's an extension of the beer place/restaurant, Suppenküche - so if you like that place, you'll def like this place. They had German beers on tap and bottle with different sizes. Didn't try any of the food, but it looked good. A lot of people were eating their pretzels. The outside setting was very nice. Nice place to drink beer and chill in an outside setting with friends. Will come again sometime soon.
author: Ada S.

description:
Once they work out all the kinks, Biergarten has a chance to be my favorite al fresco watering hole in the city. 

Now about those kinks...sure, the place is brand new, has been all over Thrillist, Daily Candy, Eater SF, Urban Daddy, Tabblehopper, Yelp, etc. etc. And opening weekend happened to be one of the nicest days of the year. So we did the smart thing and hopped in line at 2:40. We were inside right at 3pm and had no problem grabbing a table, though by the time the dust settled the line to get beer was almost as long as the line to get in the door.

Couple suggestions - maybe have an auxiliary bar set up to sell bottles of beer for those that don't want to wait for the selections out of the taps. Also, it would be great to be able to order food without waiting in that same beer line...it's possible to order pretzels from the food pick up window, why not just order all food there?

That being said, we really loved the place. Tables are communal and encourage chatting with your neighbors. The pretzel I had was fantastic, love that it's served with both mustard and horseradish. And the beer? Pretty damn good.
author: phil h.

description:
Hit the Biergarten yesterday after work around six.  No line to get in but the beer line was about five minutes.  The Swaztenbier was awesome in a great big stein and the brat was delicious.  You don't get a bun, but the hot horseradish and spicy mustard along with the sauerkraut make a meal.

The grey shipping container facilities gives the place an industrial "Sprokets" ambiance, but the bathrooms are roomy and clean.

Nice work!
author: Adam B.

description:
Great open spot with large community tables to share a few (liters of) brews with your crew(s).  The line to purchase said brew can take a while, and it gets a bit chilly after the sun goes down, but y'all probably know that already.  Layer up and you'll be just fine.  It's great to have another outdoor beer garden (see biergarten) in the city. 

Vielen dank!
author: James M.

description: A 1/2 litre of beer and a liced laced blanket.  What else can you ask for?
author: Fatty A.

description: If you are going to charge $10 for a sausage and your overhead is a shipping container on a Hayes Valley lot, you could at least get some heat lamps for your customers. Guess all that $$$ is going to rent.
author: Anthony C.

description: Not a huge selection of beer, but a great spot to hang out with friends. Its outdoors and can get chilly at times, but they provide blankets so its all good. Can get crowded so I would make sure you get there early or else you will stand around awkwardly waiting for a table. Food is good, but expensive for the portion size. Would be much better if they had some epic pretzels.
author: C W.

description:
Long lines. Get a liter, you won't want to get back in line nor lose your seat (if you can grab one).  

Could have a larger beer selection but I respect the German selection and the appropriate glassware.  High quality beer that won't get warm because you won't stop sipping.

Luckily I snagged a seat while my BF got the brews.  We arrived at 2:05, the place opened at 2:00 and already the entire garden was either packed or claimed for.  They need to have a no reserving seats rule, and a no sitting before you have beer rule and this might make the flow a little better.

I snagged the end of a table with a bit of begging and a bit of force, just after getting my beer, people were standing eyeing down seats.

Come early, bring friends, hold down a table and get a few liters.  Thank god the sun shines in SF in January.  Gotta love that.

**Did not try any food, review for beer and beer garden only**
author: Tiffany W.

description:
This little not so hidden beer garden is definitely a place to be. With long lines for a beer, you'll have to check it out. Don't fret, though, you can get 1L beer, so the wait is well worth it. The 4-5 different choices is certain to have an option for the hoppy, light, dark, and fruity loving beer go-ers. It's like $16-20 for a 1L beer, but that's almost 3 normal beers!

The crowd is anyone and everyone - you'll see hipsters, bros, older couples, college couples, etc. Everyone cozying up on the benches when it's packed.
